At first I couldn't figure out why your house had survived the holocaust while all the others hadn't. And then it occurred to me that it had been destroyed. The dwelling where you served me tea and danced your waltzes was a reproduction, something real to the touch but capable of being created and destroyed and recreated at whim.
Now you're joking with us, Captain. Can't you see it's hurting my husband?
(suddenly; fatalistically) Rishon... hear what he has to say.
More than anything, you wanted the Enterprise away from Rana. Why?

Because the house, the plot of land, your very own existence, were riddles you were helpless to explain. The warship -- another recreation -- twice tried to chase us away but failed. When I came to the house a second time I provided you with the only condition that would make the Enterprise leave -- your deaths -- and you did your best to satisfy me.
I am deeply sorry about the woman. I will help her. But I must know what you intend to do with me afterwards...
Take you to the nearest starbase where you will be held accountable for the attack on this ship... and perhaps the deaths of eleven thousand people.
No! He hasn't killed anyone!
The destruction of the planet happened just as I told you.
But you haven't told us the whole story, Kevin -- how it ended... the part about Rishon.
What is he saying... ?

I can touch you, Rishon. Hear your voice. Smell your perfume. In every respect you are a real person with your own mind and your own beliefs... but you do not exist. You died with the others, defending the colony. He has recreated you just as he has recreated the house.
You're the only living thing that really exists on Rana Four, Kevin. And though you look human, you're not.
He's in the turbolift!
Let him go.
Captain -- he is dangerous!
So dangerous, Lieutenant, he could have destroyed us at any instant he wished. Track him. Alert the crew to keep out of his way. I want him to know we mean him no harm...
Will he try to get back to the planet?
Not if he's the creature of conscience I think he is. He has someone to help first...
I have taken the music from her mind. She's alright now. She's sleeping.

(continuing; deeply sorry) She was beginning to sense who I really was. I've been living as a human for over fifty years but I couldn't hide from her. She has suffered because of my pride and selfishness. It will not happen again.
What happened on Rana Four, Kevin? The truth this time -- all of it.

Very well. For what it's worth. I am a Douwd... an immortal being of disguises and false surroundings. I have lived in this galaxy for many thousands of years although until today no one has known my true identity. Once while traveling in human form I chanced to fall in love with an Earth woman. I put aside my powers and became her husband. Our life was happy and rich. Eventually we came to this planet to live our final years. Now she is dead. She never knew what I really was...
Your colony was attacked by a warship...
Belonging to the Husnock, a species of hideous intelligence that knew only aggression and destruction. I could have destroyed them with a mere thought, but this I did not do.
You had the power to stop them and you didn't?
I refused to for the same reason I refused to stop the Enterprise. I will not kill!
So you let the colonists fight a hopeless battle.
I tried to fool the Husnock as I tried to fool you, but it only made them angrier and more cruel.
And then what you feared most happened. Rishon went to fight with the others -- and she died with them.
How I wish I could have died with her...
But you couldn't. You did the unthinkable instead. You took revenge.
Yes! I saw her broken body. I went insane! My hatred exploded and in an instant of grief I destroyed the Husnock!
Why did you try to hide this from us? Was it out of guilt for not helping Rishon and the others when they were alive?
No. You don't understand the scope of my crime. I didn't kill just one Husnock, or a hundred, or a thousand -- I killed them all. All! The mothers, the babies, all the Husnock everywhere!

Are eleven thousand people worth fifty billion? Is the love of a woman worth the destruction of an entire species... ? This is the sin I tried so hard to keep you from learning. This is why I wanted to chase you from Rana.
We are not qualified to be your judges. We have no law to fit your crime. You're free to return to the planet... and to make Rishon live again.
Helm... break orbit. Full impulse.

Captain's log, Stardate 43043.5. We are departing the Rana system for Starbase one three three. We leave behind a being of extraordinary power... and conscience. I am not certain if he should be praised or condemned. Only that he should be left alone...
Captain's log, Stardate 42881.5. We are in orbit around Antede Three, awaiting the arrival of two dignitaries from this world.
Our mission is to carry them to a conference on planet Pacifica...
... where their race will be given the opportunity to join the Federation.
I thought you might find this interesting, Mister Crusher. Few humans have ever seen an Antedian in the flesh.
Welcome. I'm Jean-Luc Picard, captain of the Enterprise.
Are they alright, Captain?
No, this is their preferred way of space travel.
Their physical condition appears good enough, considering the circumstances.
It is a self-induced catatonic state. Their way of dealing with the trauma of spaceflight.
Will we try to revive them?
Not until we reach the Pacifica conference. It's three days away. You've prepared Sickbay facilities for holding them, Doctor?
As soon as we make some adjustments. Their physiology is unusual. Can you store them for a few hours?
Aye. I'll have them kept out of the way here.
What's in this container?
Their food. When they come out of stasis, they will be very hungry.
This is what they eat?
In great quantities.
Provide security.
Understood, sir.
What a handsome race.
What did you think of the Antedians, Wesley?
Well, they are rather strange-looking, Commander.
Judging a being by its physical appearance is the last great human prejudice, Wesley.
A point well taken. I'm sure that to the Antedians, we're equally unattractive.
It is interesting to consider just how subjective "beauty" truly is...
Captain... we're being hailed by a small transport vessel just coming into range.
Oh, my God!
What is the problem?
What can she be doing here?
On the screen, Captain.
Starship Enterprise, come in!
We have you on our viewer, Pilot.
Enterprise... I have a passenger -- a V.I.P. passenger -- who I'm ordered to --
Let me talk to them, Pilot. I'm much more articulate.
Mother!
Captain, we are now receiving Starfleet orders granting a Lwaxana....
Lwaxana Troi, daughter of the Fifth House, Holder of the Sacred Chalice of Riix, heir to the Holy Rings of Betazed.
... full ambassadorial status, sir.
I'm afraid it's back into your formal uniform, Captain.
And yours too, Commander. She is listed as representing the Betazed government at the conference.
Mother, please don't do this to me.
Do what to you, Little One? Oh, what naughty thoughts, Jean-Luc. How wonderful you still think of me in that way.
It's so like my mother to do the unexpected. She's famous for it.
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

quote: It will be nice to have her as a guest of the Enterprise again.
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

quote: Energize.
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

quote: Aaagh! Where are my legs?!
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

quote: Where they belong, Mother, Right under you.
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

quote: Oh, wonderful. So they are! But I'll never completely trust this device, Jean-Luc...
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

quote: He's "Captain Picard," Mother...
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

quote: Aaagh!
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

quote: Explain.
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

quote: Sorry they startled you, Mrs. Troi. These are Antedian delegates... ah, temporarily being stored here, I believe...
scene: 11   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - PICARD, RIKER AND TROI

location: END OF HALLWAY OUTSIDE HILL'S OFFIC

quote: I don't think so.
scene: 57   INT. END OF HALLWAY OUTSIDE HILL'S OFFICE - PICARD
location: END OF HALLWAY OUTSIDE HILL'S OFFIC

quote: Come on, drop! I shot ya.
scene: 59   INT. CHANDLERLAND HALLWAY - PICARD AND TOUGHGUY

quote: No, the gun misfired. Thankfully the Holodeck is handling it correctly and the mortality failsafe is functional.
scene: 59   INT. CHANDLERLAND HALLWAY - PICARD AND TOUGHGUY

quote: But in some ways, the program is almost too accurate.
scene: 59   INT. CHANDLERLAND HALLWAY - PICARD AND TOUGHGUY

quote: Dixon, you're hurt!
scene: 59   INT. CHANDLERLAND HALLWAY - PICARD AND TOUGHGUY

quote: Don't worry about it. I'm going out for a drink.
scene: 59   INT. CHANDLERLAND HALLWAY - PICARD AND TOUGHGUY

quote: Well hello, Dixon. Haven't seen you in a while.
What's it been, four hours?
You must be Rex. Am I right?
If you gotta ask me that pal, you need a drink.
You're right, I do need a drink.
The usual?
Let's see... Scotch, neat?
What else? I hate to be the bearer of bad news old buddy, but you're leakin' blood.
So? I've got plenty more where that came from.
Geez, Dix. You're tough as nails.
Uggh, I'm going to have to get used to that.
Yeah, it's only your third one today.
What the hell... make it four.
I'll put it on your tab.
Cash! I just took on a case.
Bridge this is Doctor Pulaski. We have completed the transfer. The Antedians are now in Sickbay.
Acknowledged, Doctor. E.t.a. to Pacifica, Mister Crusher?
Twelve point four hours, sir. That will get us there approximately two hours before the conference begins.
Mother, what are you doing here? You can't just stroll up to the bridge whenever you feel like it.
I didn't just stroll up, dear. I took the turbotube, or whatever you call it. The captain's not here?
He's busy elsewhere, ma'am.
Well, no matter. I have other interests as well.
You're scheming something, Mother. I can tell.
You're always so melodramatic, Little One. I'm not scheming, I'm deciding.
Tell me Commander... what is your opinion of Betazoid women?
Well... I've only your daughter and you. But judging from that, I'd have to say they're the fairest in the galaxy.
He has excellent taste, Little One.
That's enough! This is getting embarrassing.
My lovely daughter has always found it difficult to accept compliments from male admirers. I however, long ago learned to accept them.
The key is learning how to endure constant flattery without letting it go to your head. Don't you agree, Commander?
If you say so, ma'am.
I like that answer! Now here's a man who knows how to defer to a lady. I only hope the rest of you men are listening.
... So she says "Rex, when are you gonna sell the bar and get a real job? Make a shoe, mend a fence, do something useful?" Can you believe that, Dix?
It's hard to believe, Rex.
She just doesn't understand the service I perform here. My regulars depend on me to pour and listen, listen and pour. I'm like some kind'a psychologist to you guys, am I right?
I recognize the size of the shadow.
(speaking, without turning around) Hello Slade. Buy you a drink?
Where's my Alva?
I'm working on it.
(grabbing Picard's shoulders) You're not working hard enough.
Hey pal, that's my buddy you're manhandling there! Maybe you oughta --
-- Oughta go right ahead with what you were saying.
I paid you money, Hill. Where is she?
The blood chemistry and brain organization of these creatures is completely outside of my experience... But it seems their metabolic rates are increasing.
Is that good or bad?
It's good, I think.
Pulaski to bridge.
Riker here.
The Antedians are coming around. They're currently in the early stages of post-hibernation.
How long before they're fully conscious?
I'd guess it to be a matter of hours now.
Very good, Doctor, I'll notify the captain. Riker out. If you'll excuse me, ma'am.
Are you going to see the captain? I thought he was tied up on ship's business.
In a manner of speaking... he is. I'm uh, not going to interrupt him, I'm simply going to inform him.
What excellent timing! You can also inform him about us.
Us?
You don't mind if I let your bridge crew know first, do you William?
(continuing, to everyone) Dear friends... you're all invited to a prestigious occasion on the planet Pacifica.
Oh no.
There, on the shores of the western sea... in a traditional Betazoid ceremony... your Commander Riker and I will be joined in the union of holy wedlock.
Married?
'Till death do us part.
Mrs. Troi... I don't know how to put this --
-- I know just how you feel, dear. Overwhelmed with excitement. Believe me, I understand.
We'll talk about the details later. Right now, there are preparations to be made.
Why did you stop me? Someone needs to set her straight!
I'd rather let the captain handle that.
Coward!
Simply following Starfleet's orders. Keep her mind untroubled until the conference.
Are you planing on going into the Holodeck, Commander?
Thought I might, Data. Want to come along?
I have mastered the language, or "lingo" of the period, sir. Also, the mannerisms and body language.
scene: 74   INT. HALLWAY LEADING TO HOLODECK - MATCHING CUT

quote: For example, this is a gesture denoting confidence and physical prowess. It is effective in attracting females and frightening off would-be adversaries.
scene: 74   INT. HALLWAY LEADING TO HOLODECK - MATCHING CUT

quote: Should anything in there confuse you sir, do not hesitate to ask.
scene: 74   INT. HALLWAY LEADING TO HOLODECK - MATCHING CUT

quote: It's comforting to know I'm with an expert Data, but we're really not going to be there that long. Computer...
scene: 74   INT. HALLWAY LEADING TO HOLODECK - MATCHING CUT

quote: She could be anywhere, Slade. You can't expect me to find her in one afternoon.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: It's been three days.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Has it really? What I mean is -- you gotta have patience. I'll find her; I guarantee it.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: (earnest, almost child-like) She'd contact me if she knew I was lookin' for her.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Come on, pal! So she told you that? So what? If I had a dime for every time a dame's said that to a guy --
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: -- I'd... probably have less than a dollar. Cuz a girl never says that unless she really means it.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: See? I want you to find my sister!
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: In the last program here, we said I was from South America. It seemed to explain my unorthodox appearance.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Easy Slade. They're friends of mine.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Sorry to bother you, Captain.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: -- Call me Dixon.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: -- Sorry to bother you, Dixon, but our two "passengers" are awakening.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Well then, it's time to go.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Your friends've got time for one drink, haven't they Dix?
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Sure, I can afford another round.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Very accurate. Fascinating.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: These are my associates... "Nails", from Chicago. And --
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Carlos, from South America.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Sit right down fellas, and tell me your troubles.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: Troubles I've got, sir. There's a certain woman, a wealthy and beautiful woman, who suddenly says she's going to marry me.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: She's got looks and bucks? Sounds like you've got yourself a heck of a deal.
scene: 76   INT. REX'S BAR - SAME SETTING AS BEFORE

quote: My fiance just has to see how I look in this. Come along, Homn.
scene: 77   INT. MRS. TROI'S QUARTERS - MRS. TROI (OPTICAL)

quote: Tell me, computer, is Commander Riker still on the bridge?
Negative. Riker is currently in Holodeck Three.
Holodeck? Where is that?
Follow the com panel lights. They will lead you there.
Good God, what's that?
I'll bet that's the broad with the big bucks! Come on over here, darlin'. I got the best stool in the house saved for ya.
I'm surprised you let this part of the ship get this dirty.
Actually, that's the first officer's job.
Well, as a matter of fact...
Relax, Commander. You have begun making your true feelings clear. Obviously you feel unable to handle me.
Anyway, why would a beautiful high-class lady like yourself... ... want to hook up with a mug like that? You're too good for him, if you ask me.
I couldn't agree more.
So... what'llitbe, Doll?
You are a most interesting person.
You're not so bad yourself. In fact, you're as much class as this joint's ever seen.
Here -- on the house. It's French... well, almost.
This is the most remarkable man. I have never met anyone quite like him.
I don't suppose you have.
He's strong. I feel no thoughts from him... nothing. I've never known a man so able to keep his true feelings completely hidden.
That's because...
No man has ever been such a mystery to me. I usually know their thoughts before they do.
But not me, huh?
No. And I never realized how erotic that could be. Carry my beverage to that table... we have some things to talk about.
Should we tell her?
I think it's only fair, but let's allow her the moment.
Food-food-food-food-food--
Worf! The vermicula!
Pulaski to Captain Picard.
Go ahead, Doctor.
Our passengers are on their feet.
Understood.
I had better get to the bridge.
What's their condition?
Hungry.
Coming, Mrs. Troi?
Not just yet. Tell William I'm sorry... but Rex and I are getting married.
Mrs. Troi, your government expects us to deliver you to the conference and I intend to do that!
Duty calls, darling. I'll be back for you later.
There is something about Rex I think you had better know...
Imagine -- allowing me to go on like that with a simple bartender who doesn't even exist!
Mother, you always say you like new experiences.
Why are they still here?
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: We thought that since you're going to the same conference, you might like to beam down with the other delegates.
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: They're not delegates. Those two are assassins.
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: That is... an outrage!... Lies! We demand you... transport at once!
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Oh honey, don't bother to deny it. Your minds are so unsophisticated -- I can read your thoughts in my sleep. The inside of their robes are lined with ultritium. Highly explosive and virtually undetectable by your transporter.
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: She is correct, sir. I am detecting large amounts of ultritium.
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Of course you are. They planned to blow up the entire conference.
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Take them to level five. Disarm them and hold for questioning.
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Oh well, I didn't find a mate but I saved the conference as well as your reputations. All in a day's work I suppose.
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Good-bye Mrs. Troi... and thank you.
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Jean-Luc! Shame on you for thinking such a thing!
scene: 89   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - THE TROI ENTOURAGE (OPTICAL)

quote: Chief Medical Officer's log, Stardate 44161.2. We are docked at Starbase One-Three-Three for scheduled crew rotation. I look forward to welcoming aboard my mentor, and dear friend, Doctor Dalen Quaice, who will be traveling with us to his home planet, Kenda Two.
Dalen!
It's good to see you again, Beverly.
You look wonderful.
A lie I can live with. It's kind of your captain to ferry me home.
It's on our way. Thank you, Chief.
My pleasure, Doctor.
Dalen, I was sorry to hear about Patricia.
She'd been ill for some time.
Is her death the reason you're giving up your post here?

We had a lifetime together, doing all the things we'd ever dreamed. And more. But when she was gone, I couldn't continue to work in that office, sleep in that bed without her... the absence of her was too... distracting... I'm not sure I'm making any sense.
Jack and I didn't have a lifetime, only a few short years. But I understand. When you realize someone you love is lost forever...
You know what the worst part of growing old is? So many of the people you've known all your life are gone... and you realize you didn't take the time to appreciate them while you still could...
I'm sorry. There was no reason to heap all this emotional baggage on you. I usually travel light.
Wes, time for the experiment is over... I want my warp engines back. Now.
Almost done, Commander.
Almost isn't good enough. You want to explain when the Captain says "Engage," and we just sit here?
Just a couple more minutes! I'm ready to try the new warp field! Mom?
Don't let me interrupt.
Hi!
Wes!
Right! Okay!
Computer, level two diagnostic on warp drive systems.
Antimatter containment positive. Warp drive within normal parameters.
Talk to me.
That shouldn't have happened.
Ensign Crusher --
Why would there be any visible phenomena outside the drive?
Umbilical disconnect.
Are you done?
Uh, yeah...
Clear all moorings. Engineering, aft thrusters.
Aft thrusters, aye. Impulse power to the helm.
Dalen? Dalen, it's Beverly.
Computer, current location of Doctor Dalen Quaice.
There is no Doctor Dalen Quaice aboard the Enterprise.
Doctor?
Lieutenant Worf, yesterday, before we left starbase an old friend of mine came onboard: Doctor Dalen Quaice. I requested quarters for him. He was assigned here.
I was not aware of this passenger.
I'm sorry. I thought it was standard procedure for you to be notified once Captain Picard approved passage.
It is. Please proceed.
We were to meet for breakfast. But I can't seem to find him... or any of his things...
Computer, where is Doctor Dalen Quaice?
There is no Doctor Dalen Quaice aboard the Enterprise.
Lieutenant, Doctor Quaice is very old, and rather frail. If he fell somewhere... if his communicator were damaged...
I will order a search immediately.
Thank you.
Even if Doctor Quaice had been injured... why would his belongings be missing?
Sir, I have several teams conducting a deck-by-deck search. It is not yet complete.
I have scanned the entire ship, Captain. Other than the Enterprise's regular complement, I can find no one else onboard.
Your sensors wouldn't detect him... if he were dead...
That is correct, Doctor.
Could your friend have returned to the starbase without telling you? An emergency of some sort?
There were a lot of people going back and forth between the ship and the starbase yesterday.
We can easily check the transporter I.D. traces.
By all means check the trace log. But even if the results are negative, contact Starbase Command. We should leave nothing to chance.
Yes, sir.
Doctor, one moment please. I'm sure you are aware of procedures involving passengers.
Of course. I don't know why Lieutenant Worf wasn't told about Doctor Quaice.
I was not informed either.
But I sent in a request weeks ago.
I never received it.
I'm sure I had a confirmation.
Computer, search passenger requests. Doctor Dalen Quaice.
Point of embarkation: Starbase One-Three-Three.
No listing.
Captain, I sent in that request. And it was approved.
Then it must have been intercepted before it reached me.
And someone else sent the approval? Why?
Doctor Quaice had been stationed at the starbase for some time?
Six years.
It might be prudent to find out if he'd acquired any enemies there.
On course for Durenia Four, sir.
Very good, Number One. Mister Data?
Sir, Starbase One-Three-Three has no record at all of a Doctor Dalen Quaice.
I thought he was stationed there for six years.

Not according to their computer. I have also accessed Starfleet records. There is no doctor currently serving in Starfleet named Quaice. In fact I cannot find any service record whatsoever. There are no birth records with that name. I find no --
Data, I interned with him on Delos Four. I've known him for fifteen years.
I do not doubt you, Doctor. However I have tried one hundred seventy-three phonetic variations of the name, and --
His name is Dalen Quaice. Q-U-A-I-C-E. Whatever the records say, they're wrong.
Mister Worf?
Captain, we have completed our search. We cannot locate Doctor Quaice.
You're not alone.
He was onboard. I met him in Transporter Room Three myself.
Then it appears, for reasons unknown, someone has gone to great pains to erase all traces of this man.
Who was on transporter duty when he came aboard?
Doctor Quaice? Was he part of the regular crew rotation?
No. He's a friend of Doctor Crusher's.
When did he arrive?
Sixteen hundred hours yesterday.
That was my watch. I beamed this man onboard?
Yes. I was here to greet him. An elderly man? Not in the best of health?
I'm sorry. I do remember you were here for a short while. But you were alone.
Was he invisible? Did I carry on a conversation with thin air?

No, Doctor. As far as I can recall, you came in, looked around for a few moments... I asked you if I could help you with anything... All you said was "Thank you." I said "My pleasure," or something. That was the end of it. There was no one else here.
I can't accept that Chief O'Brien might be lying...
He believes what he says. And there is no trace imprint for Doctor Quaice.
Will, I didn't conjure up one of my best friends from a test tube.
If the ship's records have been tampered with, then the transporter records could have been changed as well.
And with everybody coming and going yesterday, maybe O'Brien just doesn't remember, or...
Or?
It might be a good idea to run a diagnostic on him.
To make sure he hasn't been tampered with?
What do you think?
It's worth a try.
I'll check the replicator activity logs -- eighteen hours is a long time to go without food. Or without someone seeing him.
Chief, this examination should only take a few minutes.
But I feel fine.
Things are awfully quiet around here. Is everybody really that healthy?
I'm not complaining.
We should still have a full staff on duty.
Sit down, over here...
Doctor, it won't do any good to check my eyesight. I didn't see your friend.

(indicates examination table) I'll be a little more comprehensive than that, Chief. Crusher to Doctor Hill. Respond please. Doctor Selar, what is your present location? Computer, current whereabouts of Doctors Hill and Selar.
There is no Doctor Hill or Doctor Selar aboard the Enterprise.
I'm afraid I don't understand.
Your husband: Doctor Richard Hill...
With all due respect, you're mistaken. I'm not married.
Of course you are. Your husband is my staff osteopath. You came onboard together six months ago.
I did report for duty six months ago. But I was alone.
I am not married. I've never been married -- -- except perhaps to exobiology.
Doctors Hill and Selar, and four other members of my medical staff have all vanished. All record of their ever having been on the Enterprise has been excised from the computer's memory.
Did they come aboard with Doctor Quaice?
No. They've been here for months. But the two duty nurses don't remember them. Their families don't even remember them...
As O'Brien didn't remember Doctor Quaice... ?
I checked O'Brien thoroughly. I found no physiological abnormalities.
Crusher to Captain Picard.
Go ahead, Ensign.
I'm in Engineering, sir. I think there's something here you'd better see. It might be connected to Doctor Quaice's disappearance.
On my way.
Number One, any progress?
No one's seen him. The replicator in his quarters hasn't been used.
Check shield and hull integrity for any sign of intruders...
Yessir... but I have been closely monitoring onboard sensors... there has been no indication...
Then give me a Level One diagnostic of all onboard sensors, and run a manual sweep for any anomalous airborne or electromagnetic readings. I want some answers.
I've been experimenting with Kosinski's warp field equations... Trying to find a way to improve engine efficiency.
I've read your reports.
We did a test run while we were at the starbase.
Here's what the computer recorded.
This is the static warp field we created inside the warp drive. The experiment was designed to see if we could keep a bubble like this intact.
As you'll see in a moment, we couldn't.
There was a momentary flash of light. It was all over the spectrum.
I remember that.
Are you suggesting this bubble could have made Doctor Quaice disappear?
If he were caught in it... yessir, it would seem to us like he'd disappeared.
Where would he go?
Who knows... he could even end up outside our space-time continuum...
Was Doctor Quaice in Engineering during your experiment?
No, sir.
And this bubble never expanded beyond Engineering?
Nossir.
Then how could it have trapped Doctor Quaice or the others?
Other people are missing?
Yes, and they weren't anywhere near Engineering either.
It doesn't make sense.
And I doubt warp bubbles could alter computer records, or erase memories. Keep at it, Ensign, Mister La Forge. It's the only working theory we have for now.
Has something else happened?
Sickbay is totally empty. Apparently I no longer have any staff.
And that surprises you, Doctor?
Surprises me? I'll say it surprises me! There should be at least four members of my staff on duty at all times.
I am afraid the ship's records do not concur.
What are you talking about?
You do not have a staff.
You're telling me I'm the sole medical officer on a ship with over a thousand people on board?!
Excuse me, Doctor, but the entire ship's complement is two hundred thirty.
No. That's wrong! Whatever is happening is affecting your memories, too.
Doctor, may I see you in my Ready Room?
Beverly, you're saying this ship has lost nearly eight hundred of its personnel... ?
I know how it must sound...
None of the scans reveal any anomalies... there is no sign of an intruder... Wesley's experiment clearly did not have the scope to affect an entire starship...
The Enterprise is in serious danger. You must believe me...
I have no choice but to believe you. The safety of my crew is at stake. But I want to be sure...
That I haven't lost my mind?
I just examined myself... being the only doctor on board, I had to do it myself... there is no sign of dysfunction... yes, there's an elevation of adrenalin which I think is understandable...
Did you find anything that might suggest why you're apparently the only one among us unaffected by this... phenomenon?
No. I'll talk to Troi.
It wouldn't do any harm.
Jean-Luc, please... return to Starbase One-Three-Three for a full diagnostic. I realize you have only my word to convince you...
Mister Riker, set a course to return to Starbase One-Three-Three immediately.
Aye, sir.
Your word has always been good enough for me.

I've had a team in Sickbay for two hours. We've run the mass spectrometer on all particulates... we've scanned the EM spectrum in case a wave guide was somehow leaking radiation... we've even crawled into the life support ductwork... Captain, I don't know what this vortex was that Doctor Crusher saw...
I didn't just see it. I felt it. I barely got away from it!
Well, there's nothing there now. And no sign there ever was.
Is there any possible connection to Mister Crusher's experiment... could this warp bubble be... floating around the ship perhaps...
No, sir. The bubble was definitely contained in Engineering. There's no way it could affect something up on Deck Twelve.
Sir, I have completed level-1 computer diagnostics. There are no malfunctions.
Any other ships respond to our queries, Data?
The Wellington is the only Federation vessel in this sector... it reports normal operations. A Ferengi ship within communications range also reports nothing unusual.
Have external sensors detected anything out of the ordinary?
The interstellar medium in this sector is slightly denser than average. However, all readings are well within normal parameters.
Are all members of the crew accounted for?
Yes, doctor.
How many are there?
There are one hundred fourteen people on the Enterprise.
That is the exact number there should be.
There are now close to nine hundred missing.
Deck after deck of this ship is now deserted. How do you explain all the empty rooms? If only a hundred fourteen people are supposed to be on board, why all the extra space?
(rattling off logical explanations) Transportation of colonists... diplomatic missions... emergency evacuations...
Thank you, Mister Data.
Have security confine all nonessential personnel to their quarters. Computer, Red Alert.
Sir, I'd like Lieutenant Worf to program onboard sensors to monitor all personnel... if we can catch the exact moment someone disappears...
(gives her a blank stare) Whom did you say?
Worf... chief of security... the big guy who never smiles... Klingon?
Deanna?
I need you to tell me if I've gone completely mad.
If you can ask the question, I'd say no.
Don't evade the question.
Then ask me one I can answer.

Deanna, I've delivered babies who no longer exist! No one else remembers them. But I can close my eyes, and see their faces as clearly as I can see yours! What if it isn't some huge conspiracy?! What if it's just me?!
What if it is just you?
Then, I've delayed a mission, scared a lot of people... including me...

So what? Beverly, you've acted in the best interests of your ship and crew. What more could you ask of yourself? If it turns out to be a... mistake... we'll be a little late to Durenia Four... that's all.
It's not a mistake... I wish it were...
When we reach Starbase, I'll order a complete workup: both physical and psychological.
If we reach Starbase. Wesley... where's Wesley... ?
Wesley!!
Mom? You all right?
No. We may have very little time left...
You don't believe me...
I don't know, Mom...
I don't have time to convince you. Hundreds of people are gone and your experiment is the only possible explanation we have to work on right now...
There it is. I don't know what else to do...
Then find someone who does... someone who knows more about... about warp bubbles...
I've already talked to Kosinski on subspace... he can't explain it either and it's all based on his equations. There is someone who might be able to help us, but I can't reach him.
Who?
He was Kosinski's assistant... an alien from Tau Alpha C... He said he was a "Traveler"... somehow he combined warp technology with the energy of his own thoughts...
Yes, I remember... he took us where thoughts and reality became indistinguishable... Wesley, is it possible you've accidentally re-created something he did? Something that could alter reality?
I don't see how. But he's the only one who could tell us... I've sent a message by subspace, but Tau Alpha C is so far away, it'll take days to get there.
Maybe the Captain can help us... We've got to find him. Come on...
I don't even know if he's still alive. He was sick.
Wesley, it's a chance, we have to...
-- try it...
Nooooo... !
They're all gone... ?
Riker, Troi, Data... let me guess -- you've never heard of any of them.
Doctor, I believe I have been more than fair. I have done everything I can to substantiate your... your perceptions --
Will Riker! Your First Officer. He's very good at poker, likes to cook, listen to jazz, plays the trombone...
I cannot find any evidence...
... Commander Data, the android who sits here at Ops, dreams of being human, never gets the punch line to a joke... ?
... Beverly, we'll be arriving at Starbase One-Three-Three in a few hours...

... Deanna Troi, you ship's counselor, half-Betazoid, loves chocolate, the arrival of her mother makes you shudder? And Geordi, O'Brien, Worf... Wesley, my son -- They have been the living, breathing heart of this crew for over three years. They deserve better than to be shrugged off... brushed aside... to be pinched out of existence like this! They all do. All nine hundred. They deserve so much more...
Perhaps you should confine yourself to Sickbay until we arrive...
It's perfectly logical to you. The two of us roaming about the galaxy in the flagship of the Federation. No crew at all.
We've never needed a crew before.
I don't suppose you remember an alien from Tau Alpha C who was once onboard... called himself a Traveler... ?
Jean-Luc, I don't know how, but you and I must find this Traveler or another from his race... if anyone can help us...
You have my word... as soon as we return to the starbase, I'll make every effort to find him.
This isn't a delusion. It isn't a dream. There is a physical, measurable phenomenon at work. Maybe you can help me identify it...
How?
I'd like to use the ship's computer to monitor your life functions.
Until I disappear.
It will happen.
Very well. Computer, continuous scan: Captain Jean-Luc Picard vital signs. Audible readout. Begin now.
One ten over seventy. One ten over seventy.
I promise you I'll continue to do whatever I can to figure out what's happening, and to bring you all back. I'm sorry I lost my temper. You do remember that?
Vividly. But if I have forgotten my closest friends and comrades, as you say, I deserved every word.
For quite awhile now there's something I've been meaning to say to you. I may not get another chance. Jean-Luc, you and I --
I won't forget. I won't forget any of you!
I'm losing it... The link isn't holding, Commander!
I'll try the secondary equations!
No, it's too late. Look.
I've lost it.
I'm sorry, Wesley.
It's over. We'll never get her back.
It's not over, Wesley.
There's still a way.
Captain's log, Stardate 44162.5. Two attempts to retrieve Doctor Crusher have failed. And now the Traveler, a mysterious visitor from our past, has reappeared.
And then I sent a message by subspace to Tau Alpha C asking for help... but I didn't think it would reach there for days...
Actually, it didn't reach me... not by subspace...
Then how did you know about the warp bubble?
It would take too long to explain...
Is she alive?
(reassuring, authoritative) As long as she thinks she is alive, she is alive.
What the hell does that mean?

(sighs with controlled frustration) Your species have very narrow perceptions of time and space and thought. (beat, trying to make it simple) When Beverly Crusher was caught in the static warp bubble, she created her own reality. Her thoughts at the precise moment she was trapped determined its shape and form.
Can you go in and get her back?
No, it is her reality. I cannot enter it... any more than I can enter her thoughts.
But you said there's still a way.

I can help, but I can't do it myself. Wesley, there is a power within each of us that most people haven't begun to realize... you have, or I would not have known to come here now... Together, we may be able to open a gateway for her. But she must choose to walk through it.

Computer, we're going to apply precise diagnostic methodology. Once we've cataloged the symptoms, we'll proceed to determine the illness, and find a cure. We'll start with the assumption that I'm not crazy... if I am, it won't matter one way or the other...
Computer, read the entire crew roster for the Enterprise.
Doctor Beverly Crusher.
Have I always been the only member of the crew on the Starship Enterprise?
Affirmative.
If this was a bad dream, would you tell me?
That information is not available.
What date did I report on board?
Stardate 41154. Fourteen hundred hours, three minutes.
That sounds about right. Computer, is there more than one U.S.S. Enterprise?
This vessel is the fifth starship to bear the name U.S.S. Enterprise. It is currently the only one in service.
What is the primary mission of the Starship Enterprise?
To explore the galaxy.
Do I have the necessary skills to complete that mission alone?
Negative.
Then why am I the only crew member? Aha, gotcha there...
That information is not available.
Computer, are you familiar with the inhabitants of Tau Alpha C?
Affirmative.
Are any presently located on a starbase or vessel within communication range?
Negative.
Estimated time to Tau Alpha C at warp nine-point-five...
One hundred twenty-three days.
Lay in a new course for Tau Alpha C. And send them a subspace message advising our arrival.
Acknowledged.
Engage.
Computer, did you change course?
State new destination or coordinates.
I stated it, dammit... Tau Alpha C...
There is no Tau Alpha C listed on current star maps...
Captain's log, stardate 44162.8. At the direction of the Traveler, the Enterprise is returning to Starbase One-Three-Three and the precise position where the subspace bubble was formed.
Our goal will be to create a stable gateway between our reality and your mother's reality...
We've tried to stabilize it. The link won't hold.
Of course not. The equations are only the first step. We will be going beyond mathematics.
Just tell me what I have to do.
It's nothing I can tell you, Wesley...
Then how am I supposed to do it? (off the Traveler's even stare) You said you'd help.
You must allow me to help.
I don't know how.
Begin by letting go of your guilt, Wesley.
It was my fault. I should never have tried...
Focus on the present. You will have to be here... completely... to help her back. You must open yourself to time and space and the intricate threads that bind them.
Begin entering your warp field equations...
Close your eyes.
Continue to enter the equations...
I don't have any more equations.
See past the numbers. Trust yourself...
I can't. I can't do it.
When the time comes, you will, Wesley. You will. Now, begin again...
Starbase One-Three-Three, this is the Enterprise. Starbase One-Three-Three, this is the Enterprise. Please acknowledge. Viewscreen on.
It's not just people... Everything is disappearing!
Computer, what is that... mist... I'm seeing?
Sensors indicate it to be a mass-energy field seven hundred and five meters in diameter.
It surrounds the ship?
Affirmative.
If there isn't anything wrong with me... maybe there's something wrong with the universe... Computer, what is beyond the mass-energy field?
Sensors cannot penetrate the field.
Computer, here's a question you shouldn't be able to answer... What is the nature of the universe?
The universe is a spherical region seven hundred and five meters in diameter.
Approaching Starbase One-Three- Three, Captain...
Slow to ten meters per second.
Mister La Forge, prepare for precision station-keeping.
Acknowledged. Readying thrusters.
There... there it is...
We're moving into phase now ... there's your warp bubble, Wesley...
What? What's wrong.
It's collapsing.
Computer, give me a graphic representation of the universe.
I've seen that before... Wesley's experiment... the bubble. Of course... But that would mean I'm the one trapped in the bubble...
Computer, what's happening?
Explosive decompression: Decks Five through Fourteen. Sealing off forward sections.
Cause?
A flaw in the ship's design.
Show me.
Analysis... ?
No ship's structures exist forward of Bulkhead Three-Four-Two.
Superimpose the previous image over this one. Same scale. And continue to monitor.
It's collapsing...
Hull integrity now compromised on Decks Three through Fifteen.
How long can life support be maintained?
Four minutes, seventeen seconds.
Sir, we have reestablished the exact coordinates and attitude.
Geordi, we're in position... your status?
The warp bubble is contracting at a rate of fifteen meters per second... we'll lose it in about four minutes...
It's time, Wesley.
We're ready, Commander.
Proceed.
I'll be in Engineering.
Let it go, Wesley... let go of the anticipation... the expectations... the demands upon yourself... let it all go... leave it behind.
Yes. The ability is there... inside you... you don't need to look for it...
Three minutes thirty seconds to life support failure.

(to herself, quick pace, pressing herself to complete equation) The Traveler used his thoughts to alter warp fields... and thoughts became reality... Now I'm in a warp field... Could my thoughts have changed this reality?

Come on, Beverly! What's the next step?! What was I thinking at the moment Wesley's bubble formed? Dalen Quaice... He said... all the people he'd known were gone... I thought of Jack... I went to see Wesley... the flash in Engineering... And that's when it started... when I started losing everybody! My thoughts created this universe. Can they get me out of it again?
That information is not available.
I'm not talking to you. Click my heels together three times and I'm back in Kansas? Can it be that simple?
No, it can't be that simple.
Two minutes thirty seconds to life support failure.
Computer, hypothetical situation... a person is trapped inside a static warp bubble. Determine a means of escape...
Escape would theoretically depend on establishing a stable threshold between the warp field and the outer environment.
Can you describe this threshold?
Negative. There are no known practical applications of this theory.
Extrapolate from theoretical database. How might it manifest itself?
A dynamic atmospheric disturbance of great intensity.
Disturbance? The vortex! They must have been trying to reach me! But how do I find it... ? Wesley, where do I go? Help me...
Stable threshold... They've been trying to create a stable threshold. Where are they trying to do it? (the final piece of the puzzle) Where did they do it the first time? Engineering!
One minute thirty seconds to life support failure.
Engineering!
Failure in Turboshaft Four. Unable to proceed to Main Engineering.
Just get me anywhere on Deck Thirty-Six!
We're losing the bubble...
Jean-Luc... (sees the Traveler, reacts) You...
Do I have you to thank for getting me back?
No.
Captain, if I may ask: how many people are there onboard?
One thousand fourteen, including your guest, Doctor Quaice.
Is there something wrong with that count?
No. That's the exact number there should be.
Tarchannen Three Investigation. Stardate 40164.7. Ensign Anthony Brevelle Recording. Lieutenant Susanna Leijten in command.
You up and running, Brevelle?
Yes, Lieutenant.
I've checked buildings Four and Five... they're like all the others... no phaser hits, no sign of a fight. Looks like the entire outpost just... vanished...
Lieutenant Leijten...
You'd better come see this...
No footprints... no vehicle tracks. The wind probably erased them... but look...
Freeze visual.
That's Hickman on the right... that's Mendez on the left... and as already noted, the recording was made by Ensign Brevelle... five years ago...
Commander Leijten, you said Brevelle was ill last week for several days before he... deserted. What about Mendez?
Mendez was last seen aboard the Aries an hour before she disappeared. According to witnesses, she seemed completely normal.
And Hickman?
He just passed a routine physical... with flying colors.
I know Paul Hickman. He's a family man... two kids. I can't believe he'd steal a shuttle and desert...
Believe it, Geordi. He was spotted by a Federation supply ship yesterday... on a course toward Tarchannen Three.
The original Tarchannen disapperances were never solved, were they?
No... we never learned what happened or why. Forty-nine people... gone...
And now, five years later, members of the away team that investigated the disappearances... have started disappearing themselves.
Geordi and I are the only two left.
Captain's log, Stardate 44664.5. We have set a course to intercept Lieutenant Hickman's stolen shuttlecraft... and, hopefully, to discover the whereabouts of the other missing officers...
And then I almost married Paul Bogrow...
Bogrow... which one was he?
You remember... with the thin moustache...
Not Bogrow...
I know.
The one who used to drive you crazy... you thought he was so full of himself...
Well, I decided I prejudged him unfairly...
Uh huh...
And then I decided I'd been right in the first place.
(laughs, shakes his head) Bogrow...
And what about you... how come you never found the right girl?
I enjoy the bachelor's life too much...
That doesn't sound like my "little brother" who always wanted advice on women...
Well, you were obviously a great advisor...
What do you think, Suz?
I don't know. But I'm not ashamed to tell you... I'm a little scared, you know?
Yeah, I know.
Well, if anybody's gonna figure this out, it'll be the Leitjen and La Forge Show, right? We always made a good team...
A helluva team...
Commander La Forge, Commander Leijten, report to the Bridge. We have a fix on the missing shuttle.
On our way, Commander.
Entering the Tarchannen system, sir.
Slow to impulse power. Mister Worf?
Long range sensors holding on the shuttlecraft... bearing zero one zero, mark two seven one.
Hail the vessel.
Lieutenant Hickman is not responding, sir.
Put a repeating message on all sub-space channels. Make it a Priority One communique -- order the Lieutenant to come about and stand to.
Still no response, sir.
The craft is now within visual range.
On screen.
The shuttle's acceleration is increasing... its trajectory is moving directly into the planet's atmosphere.
He will reach an atmospheric interface at an altitude of two hundred and ten kilometers.
At his current speed, he'll self-destruct.
That is correct, Commander.
How soon, Data?
Fifty-three seconds.
Options?
He's out of transporter range.
And he's too far away for a positive lock with the tractor beam.
Open a channel.
Open.
Lieutenant Hickman, listen carefully. I am Captain Picard of the Enterprise. You are in danger. You must slow your rate of approach.
The shuttle is approaching the outer thermosphere, Captain.
He's panicking...
At current rate of acceleration, the shuttlecraft will be destroyed in twenty-eight seconds.
Sixteen seconds to impact.
Lieutenant Hickman, you must do as I tell you. Reduce your velocity and bring your craft to a positive pitch of twenty degrees... now.
The shuttle is entering the lower ionosphere...
Sir, sensors detect two more Federation shuttlecraft on the planet's surface... no life signs.
Ready an away team, Number One.
Geordi, Data, Worf...
And Commander Leijten.
Commander Leijten, La Forge, check the shuttle... Worf, Data, you've got the perimeter.
It's the shuttle pod Mendez stole from the Aries...
No life signs, sir.
Sir... I am certain that we are being watched.
Commander Riker...
Where's Commander Leijten?
Susanna, report.
Fan out. Let's find her.
Susanna?
La Forge to Leijten...
Over here...
Where have you been?
Mendez... Brevelle... they're alive. You saw the footprints?
Yes... but they're not human...
They're here. Stand still... listen... and you can feel it... they're here...
I'm not picking up anything...
Where are you going?
Susanna... ?
La Forge to Enterprise, medical emergency, two to Sickbay.
Do I look as bad as I feel?
You look fine... now.
What happened?
Your blood chemistry is way off. And you had a histamine response, to what I don't know. I'll run a complete blood and tissue analysis.
I need to get back to the surface.
Uh uh... until we find some answers, I don't want you to leave the Enterprise.
But I have work...
Look, Commander, you may simply have had an anxiety reaction down there. But we've got to make sure.
Probably wouldn't hurt to take it easy for a while...
I'm not going to stay locked up on this ship while the investigation...
Your devotion to duty is admirable, Commander... but Doctor Crusher is right. You will remain on the Enterprise until we know whether or not this is connected to the disappearance of the others.
Captain...
We have completed our survey on the surface. Analyzing that data will keep all of us busy for some time.
Of course, sir. I understand.
Data has a preliminary report... if you feel up to it...
Sure... what're we waiting for?
Doctor... what about La Forge?
I gave him a complete bioscan. Everything says he's in perfect shape.
But according to all reports... so were Mendez and Hickman before they disappeared.

Captain Picard's wrong. The way to handle this is to get back down there with a dozen away teams... fan out from the shuttle... We can cover a lot of ground in a hurry... use proximity detectors and infrared sensors...
Susanna...
Geordi... it's started... whatever happened to the others... it's happening to me, too...
Suz... I'm here... I'm not going to let anything happen to you.
Main Bridge.
During microscopic examination of the torn uniform, I discovered these alien skin cells.
Source?
Undetermined.
Without something else to cross-reference, it would take weeks to try and identify them...
Fortunately, there is more evidence...
We have been able to determine that the footprints we found by the shuttle were not made by any known Tarchannen life form.
If we're pursuing a theory that somehow unknown aliens are involved... I should tell you we didn't find tracks like that during the original investigation.
The planet is subject to frequent sandstorms. Footprints could have been obliterated prior to your arrival.
Doctor Crusher and I will begin to search the medical database... and attempt to match these with a known life form.
Aliens or no aliens... why would our people start returning after five years to be... abducted?
Some kind of compulsion... like a post hypnotic command... ?
Something that happened while we were down there the first time...
We can go back to the mission record... construct a log of everyone's movements...
And look for a commonalty. Something we all touched... maybe a plant... the sand...
Or something we ingested... could be in the air itself...
The parameters are pretty broad, Data... any match we make is going to be inconclusive at best.
scene: 31   INT. BEVERLY'S OFFICE - TO INCLUDE WALL MONITOR

quote: I am aware of that. However, I see no other reasonable course of investigation available to us. And we may not have much time.
scene: 31   INT. BEVERLY'S OFFICE - TO INCLUDE WALL MONITOR

quote: You're worried about Geordi, aren't you?
scene: 31   INT. BEVERLY'S OFFICE - TO INCLUDE WALL MONITOR

quote: I am an android. It is not possible for me to feel anxiety. Starfleet personnel have vanished... others may be at risk. We must do the best we can to find out why.
scene: 31   INT. BEVERLY'S OFFICE - TO INCLUDE WALL MONITOR

quote: However...
scene: 31   INT. BEVERLY'S OFFICE - TO INCLUDE WALL MONITOR

quote: I am strongly motivated to solve this mystery.
scene: 31   INT. BEVERLY'S OFFICE - TO INCLUDE WALL MONITOR

quote: Freeze visual.
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: We're wasting our time.
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: You didn't feel that way before... it was your idea to look for some sort of commonality.
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: Well... I was wrong.
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: We're not going to find anything this way. We should go back to the planet... it's all down there... everything we need to know.
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: That's not an option... not until the Captain says it is...
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: Computer resume.
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: I can't look at this anymore. It hurts my eyes... I can't think. My brain feels like it's wrapped in a blanket.
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: Take a break. I'll work for a...
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: I don't need a break... I... ... I need to get off this ship.
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: I think... we should go see Doctor Crusher...
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: Forget Crusher... forget your logs. Tarchannen's down there, Geordi. It's waiting for us. That's where we should go.
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: Susanna... you can't leave...
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: Susanna...
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: SUSANNA!
scene: 32   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: Her blood pressure's still falling... Apply the T-cell stimulator. We've got to stabilize her immune system.
She's developed an extreme sensitivity to light... we're trying to make her more comfortable.
My God...
Geordi...
Hold on, Susanna. Doctor Crusher will help you. Just... hold on.
It's inside me, Geordi... I can't fight it... it's winning...
Don't give up... do you hear me, Suz? You can't give up...
This is one of Susanna's altered skin cells...
And this is one of the alien cells Data found.
Almost identical. How do you explain it?
Captain, I think the people who disappeared from Tarchannen Three weren't abducted... they were transformed into another species...
Can you stop it, Doctor?
The T-cell stimulator will slow the rate of change... but until I find the cause...
Doctor Crusher... is this a threat to the Enterprise?
No. I've tested the cell wall integrity. It's viability is extremely low. It's not possible for Susanna to transmit it.
Then how did she get it?
That's a good question. And it would be a great help if I knew. The only thing I do know, Geordi... is that it's very possible you'll be next.
I had two full bioscans today. You said I was fine.
I gave Susanna a bioscan, too. I didn't find anything wrong with her, either.
How long?
I don't know what we're dealing with. Brevelle was sick for days before he left... Mendez was normal an hour before she disappeared. You may have weeks... or just a few hours.
(after a thoughtful beat) Then there's no time to waste. I've got to get back to work.
Geordi... until I know exactly what we're dealing with, you're staying here. In Sickbay.
Doctor, you said it would help if you knew the source of this...
If I could finish my analysis of the mission records... I might find an answer.
And what if you begin to change... and feel compelled to return to the planet like the others?
Program the computer to monitor my movements... that way you can be sure I don't leave the ship.
What would you do, sir? Sit it out in Sickbay... or try to learn what it is that's got you... and maybe stop it?
All right, Mister La Forge... proceed with your investigation. But report to Doctor Crusher for another bioscan at the start of day watch.
In the meantime, if you have symptoms of any kind -- I want to know. Immediately.
Understood.
One to transport.

quote: Okay, computer...

quote: No audio anomalies present.

quote: It's not.

quote: Have you done an audio analysis...

quote: And a spectrographic analysis and a screen for ionizing radiation... and I even ran an enhancement for micro-seismic disturbances. I've tried it all.
scene: 42   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: I'm sorry, Data.
scene: 42   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: There is no need for an apology.
scene: 42   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: Perhaps if you indulged in a short rest period, you could approach this problem with what humans commonly refer to as a fresh point of view...
scene: 42   INT. ENGINEERING - GEORDI'S OFFICE - ON WALL MONITOR

quote: You're probably right, Data. But I've got to finish scanning these records... while I can.

quote: Is there some way I can assist you?
