quote: Sorry to disturb you, Doctor...
It's alright. What's happened?
I thought you should see this.
Her skin's simulating the light... a radiant reaction... Some sort of mimetic ability?
That's not all. Her body temperature is dropping.
It's as if she's generating a disruptive field... I can barely get readings off her now... What about her rate of transformation?
It's increasing.
That's not possible. It should have been inhibited by the T-cell stimulator... unless... If there's a foreign body inside her that's producing these changes... something like a viral creche...
A very small one if our scans haven't found it.
I want a full genetic analysis. We're going to examine any abnormality we find... no matter how insignificant it seems.
One to transport.
Computer, delete the audio.
Wait a minute... freeze visual.
Whose shadow is that?
Please restate question.
Computer... the shadow currently displayed in section B-eleven... what is its source?
Unknown.
It's gotta belong to somebody... Computer... return to time index fourteen five eight...
Okay... Brevelle's behind the camera... Susanna and I head off in that direction. Mendez moves off that way... ... so whose shadow is it?
Computer... replay visual from last time index. No audio. Slow to fifty percent.
Freeze visual.
Magnify four times... apply spectral enhancement.
Computer, do you have sufficient data to compile a Holographic simulation of this Visual Record?
A simulation would be limited to areas scanned by the visual recording device.
Good. Fine. Scan the entire record... then recreate it in Holodeck Three.
Computer, is the Tarchannen simulation ready?
Affirmative. Program complete. Enter when ready.
Computer, scan Starfleet records and create a simulation of Brevelle... place him where he stood while recording this...
Good. Computer, based on their speed and direction, can you extrapolate each officer's movements as they walk out of the recording device's field of view?
Affirmative. With an increasing probability of error, reaching ninety-five percent after ten seconds.
Understood. Run simulation.
I want to make another sweep of the perimeter. Mendez, Brevelle, start at Building Two. La Forge, you and I will begin at Four.
It's happening too fast. Freeze program.
Computer, reverse simulation... run it back to... time index fourteen five eight.
Freeze.
Computer... remove Leijten...
Remove La Forge...
... and now remove Mendez...
Computer, using vector analysis, identify the source of this shadow.
There is no object in the program which could generate the shadow.
There must be something else here... something between the camera lights and the wall.
Computer, given the distance from the lights to the wall... can you determine the most likely shape and position of the object casting this shadow?
There is insufficient data to reconstruct the requested object.
Okay... let's assume the height of our friend here is about my size... say one hundred seventy centimeters... now can you extrapolate its shape and position?
Affirmative.
Do it.
There... in the thymus...
(studying the figures, puzzled) Some kind of parasite. It's using Susanna's immune system to spread genetic instructions...
How did it get there?
She could have been infected during the original mission. It's small enough to have entered through any of the mucous membranes...
But it certainly isn't acting like a typical parasite... it's not feeding off her -- it's actually transforming her DNA to match its own...
There's not much of her original DNA left.
And we're going to need unaltered genes... or we'll never get her back. We've got to get that thing out of her. Now.
Any luck?
Negative, Commander. Nothing in our survey suggests the source of a parasitic infection...
Crusher to Bridge.
Go ahead, Doctor.
The surgery was successful...
... but it will be a few hours before we know how her regenerative systems are responding... In the meantime, I'd better get Geordi in here.
Very good, Doctor. Keep us advised.
Crusher to La Forge...
Computer, locate Commander La Forge.
Commander La Forge is not on board the Enterprise.
Bridge, the Computer says Geordi isn't on board... ? Is that correct?
I show no transporter activity.
All shuttles are secure.
Negative, Doctor. There is no indication he left the ship.
Computer, what was Commander La Forge's last known location?
Holodeck Three.
Worf...
Captain, if Geordi has transformed, he may be virtually a chameleon -- the skin develops mimetic capabilities... he could still be onboard...
... but undetectable to our sensors...
Search the structure... I will take the perimeter...
Commander...
Security...
Captain... the security lockout on Transporter Room Six has been broken.
Re-engage... now.
I cannot, sir... The transport cycle has already begun.
I do not read any life signs on the surface.
Our sensor array is useless... we have to find another way of locating him.
Captain, if we can get close enough to Geordi... we can read his absorption spectrum with an ultraviolet light.
Can you modify an emergency beacon to operate on UV?
Yes, sir.
Make it so. Number One, as soon as Data is ready, I want you to lead an away team.
How long, Mister Data?
(continuing to work as he talks) I still must replace the emitter module and reconnect the power supply. It will take approximately two minutes to complete the modification.
Hedrick to Commander Riker.
Go ahead.
I've been able to determine La Forge's transport coordinates.
He beamed down next to the Aries shuttle.
Acknowledged.
He's on foot... couldn't have gotten far by now. Let's assume a radius of ten kilometers...
That is still a search area of more than three hundred square kilometers.
We've got to narrow it down. What's happening with the enhanced sensor arrays?
All scans are still negative.
There has to be some way to track him. What about the high resolution EM scans?
We are adjusting the sensors to read Commander La Forge's absorption spectrum... but it will take several hours.
Geordi doesn't have several hours.
I have completed the modifications, Commander.
Doctor Crusher... meet us in Transporter Room Six. Immediately.
... And I'm going to need a sedative for him... Get me ten cc's of kayolane...
Doctor Crusher...
You look a lot better than you did an hour ago...
What did you do?
We removed some kind of parasite from your thymus...
No. It wasn't a parasite, Doctor. (with new found inner knowledge) It's their method of reproduction... to plant a DNA strand in a living host... that causes a metamorphosis. ... Geordi?
He's gone...
Yes...
He's on the planet...
Don't try to get up yet...
We have to find him...
An away team is about to start a search.
You'll never be able to find him... I'm the only one who can.
No... you must turn them off... the light frightens them...
(to Susanna; re: the emergency beacon) What about the ultraviolet?
That is beyond their visual spectrum... they will not run from it.
He could be several kilometers away by now.
No... he's here... they're all here...
There.
Geordi...
Geordi... stop...
Wait here...
Geordi, my voice is familiar... listen to it... you can feel that we share this... you know I am not a threat...
The others... Mendez, Brevelle, they no longer exist as humans... but a part of you still does. You are not one of them... not yet. I can help you... if you'll just trust me...
I know what's going on inside you... the war you're fighting with yourself... the humanity slipping away... the instinct to run... It's overpowering, but they know how to beat it now...
Look at me... I've come back... Let me take you back, too.
Just take my hand... please...
Crusher to Enterprise. Lock on to Commander Leitjen's signal... prepare to transport two directly to Sickbay.
We're going home, Geordi.
Is there no hope for the others? Brevelle, Mendez...
None.
Susanna...
I'm here, Geordi. So's Doctor Crusher and Captain Picard.
Lieutenant Commander La Forge reporting for duty, Captain.
Welcome back, Mister La Forge.
This species... can we communicate with them?
No. They act on instinct alone. In another few minutes, I wouldn't have responded to you at all, Susanna.
Then we shall leave them be. I'll order warning beacons placed in orbit and on the surface. Hopefully, no one else will have to go through what you did.
Down there, I didn't know who you were... and yet somehow I believed you... trusted you...
Must've been all the good advice I used to give you...
Thank you.
Captain's log: Stardate 44429.6. We are on a mapping survey near the Cardassian sector. It has been nearly a year since a peace treaty ended the long conflict between the Federation and Cardassia.
Captain, we are nearing the periphery of Sector twenty-one-five-oh-three.
Be on the lookout for a Cardassian patrol vessel, Mister Worf. They should be hailing us soon.
Even with a treaty, they're skittish about protecting their borders.
Last time I was in this sector, I was on the Stargazer, running at warp speed ahead of a Cardassian warship.
Running, Captain? You? That's hard to believe...

Believe it. I'd been sent to make preliminary overtures to a truce... I lowered my shields as a gesture of good will. But the Cardassians weren't impressed. They took out most of my weapons and damaged the impulse engines before I could regroup and run.
The Cardassians have no honor. I do not trust them.
They're our allies now, Worf. We have to trust them.
Trust is earned, not given away.
Well, I hope their scout vessel makes contact soon. It's not a good idea to stay too long on a Cardassian border without making your intentions known.
What is it?
Kelp buds... plankton loaf... and sea berries.
Sweetheart... I'm not a fish.
It's very healthy. I had this for breakfast every morning when I was growing up.
No oatmeal -- or muffins? How about corned beef and eggs?
For breakfast?
Keiko, I've been thinking... You've introduced me to all the wonderful foods you're accustomed to... I'd like to do the same. Isn't that what marriage is about? Sharing?
Like what kind of food?
Scalloped potatoes... mutton shanks... oxtails and cabbage...
Kind of... heavy...
No, you'll love it, I promise. I can still remember the aromas when my mother was cooking...
She cooked?
She didn't believe in a replicator. She thought real food was more nutritious.
She handled... real meat... touched it and cut it?
Like a chef. She was fantastic. Of course, I'll have to use the replicator... but I'll make something special for you tonight. You'll love it, I promise.
Okay. Maybe I'll have something special for you, tonight, too...
Something's wrong...
Red alert. Take emergency stations.
Cardassian ship preparing to fire again, sir!
Increase power to forward shields!
Hail them again, Mister Worf.
What is he doing? Damage report!
Minor damage to secondary hull before we put our shields up, sir. No casualties, structural integrity intact.
Engineering to Bridge... starboard power coupling is down...
Evasive action -- Delta Sequence. Mister Worf, ready phasers.
Delta Evasion Plan initiated...
Mister Worf, limit targets to engines and shields...
Aye sir... ready...
Fire.
Direct hit, sir. Moderate damage to their aft shield generators...
Continue phaser fire.
Multiple hits. Power failure in forward shields...
Cardassian ship is standing down, sir.
Let's see if they'll answer our hail now, Mister Worf.
Frequency open, sir.
This is Captain Jean-Luc Picard, of the Federation Starship Enterprise.
I am Gul Macet of the Cardassian ship Trager.
Why have you fired on us?
A curious question. In war, one attacks one's enemies.
There is a treaty between our people...
Perhaps that fact was unknown to the Federation starship which destroyed our space station in the Cuellar System two days ago.
A Federation starship... ?
Attacked an unarmed science station. They had barely enough time to send an emergency signal... before they were incinerated.
Gul Macet... the Federation and the Cardassians have struggled too hard for peace to abandon it so easily...
We are not the ones who abandoned it, Captain.
Let me talk to my superiors... find out what's behind this. Give me one hour. The alternative is for us to continue firing at each other. In such a contest, you would be at a disadvantage.
Very well. One hour.
We've confirmed the report, Captain. It was the starship Phoenix... under the command of Benjamin Maxwell.
scene: 13   INT. READY ROOM - CLOSE ON MONITOR - INTERCUTTING

quote: Ben Maxwell... he's one of Starfleet's finest Captains... he must have had provocation.
scene: 13   INT. READY ROOM - CLOSE ON MONITOR - INTERCUTTING

quote: I wish we knew. He's gone on silent running... doesn't answer our communiques.
scene: 13   INT. READY ROOM - CLOSE ON MONITOR - INTERCUTTING

quote: Then he's still in Cardassian space.
scene: 13   INT. READY ROOM - CLOSE ON MONITOR - INTERCUTTING

quote: The station he destroyed was in sector twenty-one-five-oh-five -- you're the nearest starship. We want you to go in and find him.
scene: 13   INT. READY ROOM - CLOSE ON MONITOR - INTERCUTTING

quote: Will the Cardassians cooperate... ?
scene: 13   INT. READY ROOM - CLOSE ON MONITOR - INTERCUTTING

quote: They've granted you safe passage... We've agreed that you'll take along a delegation of observers as a show of good faith. Jean-Luc... I don't have to tell you the Federation is not prepared for a new sustained conflict. You must preserve the peace... no matter what the cost. Haden out.
scene: 13   INT. READY ROOM - CLOSE ON MONITOR - INTERCUTTING

quote: ... there will be three Cardassians transporting on board... Their Captain, Gul Macet and two of his aides. My intention is to be as open as possible with them... allow them to share in our search for the Phoenix.
Sir, it is necessary to assign them a security detail.
They will be our guests, Mister Worf. I don't want them to feel like prisoners.
I'm inclined to agree with Worf, Captain. I would limit their access while they're on board. They don't need the run of the ship.
I understand your concerns. And I realize... that we have had a long and difficult history with the Cardassians.
However... it is not an exaggeration to say that the difference between peace... and war... is up to us. And the way we treat the Cardassians may make the difference.
At least let me post guards at some of the sensitive areas of the ship.
Very well, we will limit their access. But instruct your people... they are guests.
Counselor, stay close to the crew. Some of them might be uncomfortable with the Cardassians on board. I want no incidents.
Yes, Captain.
Mister Data, is there anyone on board who served previously with Captain Benjamin Maxwell?
Accessing... Chief O'Brien served under his command aboard the Rutledge.
Very well. Mister Riker... Counselor... you will greet our guests in Transporter Room Three. And advise Chief O'Brien that I will be calling on him.
Yes, sir.
The delegation is ready to come aboard, sir.
I believe you served under Benjamin Maxwell?
Captain Maxwell? I'm proud to say I did.
It seems Maxwell has taken it upon himself to destroy a Cardassian space station.
If that's true, sir, there was a reason for it. I'd bank my life on that.
The Captain may want to talk to you about him. Bring them aboard.
Welcome to the Enterprise. I am First Officer William Riker... this is Counselor Deanna Troi.
I am Gul Macet... my aides, Glinn Daro and Glinn Telle.
Our Transporter Chief, Mister O'Brien.
Captain's Log, supplemental: We have entered Cardassian territory, and are proceeding in our quest to locate the Phoenix.
... and with long-range sensors, we've been scanning a radius of ten light years. We can effectively scan one sector in a day.
We are scanning Sector twenty-one-five-oh-five now. So far... no sign of the Phoenix.
In fact, you have no assurance that the ship is still in Sector twenty-one-five-oh-five.
In fact, we don't have any idea where it is. But the last known co-ordinates seemed like a reasonably good place to start.
(jumping in to keep it smooth) We would welcome any additional intelligence your forces could provide.
Captain Picard... you can understand that we are skeptical. Do you expect us to believe that you are using every means at your disposal -- to track down one of your own?

Of course you would have concerns, Gul Macet. It is precisely because of that fact that I am including you in every aspect of our effort. You are here, with my staff, hearing reports as I hear them. Nothing is edited... nothing withheld.
Please. Let us continue.
Very well.
Our Transporter Chief, Mister O'Brien, has served with Benjamin Maxwell. I thought he might provide some insights.
Mister O'Brien... I believe Captain Maxwell lost his family... during a raid on an outpost.
More like sabotage, sir. It was on Setlik Three. A squad of Cardassian militia made a sneak attack on an outpost... wiped out close to a hundred civilians.
Then it's vengeance he's after.
That's not what I meant --
Maxwell's taking retribution for his own loss.
Captain Maxwell would never --
Gentlemen, please. Let us avoid speculation, and confine this discussion to facts. Now, Mister O'Brien --
Worf to Captain Picard.
Yes, Lieutenant.
Captain -- long range sensors have located the Phoenix.
Will you join me on the Bridge?
Deck six.
Deck ten.
Your Captain is most impressive.
Yes. He is.
Chief O'Brien... our Transporting system is still operating with active feed pattern buffers. I would like to talk with you about your technology.
I'll have to get Commander La Forge's approval on that.
I understand. In the meantime... we're going to your Ten-Forward. Will you join us?
If my commander tells me to discuss the Transporter with you, I will. If Captain Picard orders me to tell you everything I know about Ben Maxwell, I will.
But who I choose to spend my free time with... that's my business.
We have located the Phoenix in Sector twenty-one-five-oh-five.
Ensign, set a course -- warp six. Mister Worf, send a message by sub-space. Tell them to prepare to rendezvous with us.
Yes, Captain.
Captain... a suggestion.
Yes?

We have a number of ships in sector twenty-one-five-oh-five. If you give us more precise coordinates... and the ship's coded transponder frequency... we could intercept Maxwell much more quickly than you.
I'm sure that's true. However, given the circumstances, I'd prefer to make the initial contact myself. As I'm sure you would if the situation were reversed.
Time is crucial. You have a dangerous man out there, with a huge arsenal at his command. If he's bent on revenge against my people... he must be stopped before he can do more damage.

At the moment, we have an isolated incident. If I reach him first, diplomatic efforts can still prevail. But if one of your ships decides to retaliate against the Phoenix... we risk losing control of the situation.
Then you won't give us the means of finding his exact location?
No. I will not.
There you are... potato casserole -- a dish fit for kings.
... minstrel boy to the war is gone...
What's that you're singing?
What? Oh... just an old song...
A bunch of us used to sing it together... on the Rutledge. I haven't thought about it for years...
What's it about?

Oh... about war, and glory... "The minstrel boy to the war is gone; In the ranks of death you'll find him; His father's sword he hath girded on; And his wild harp slung behind him." ... Captain Maxwell always liked that song... I guess all this business with him and the Cardassians... brought it back.
You know... sitting with the staff this morning, I could tell there were people in that room who still don't like the Cardassians.
I imagine that's to be expected...
You do?
The war lasted a long time. That takes its toll on people. What are these little black things?
Capers. But the fighting is over now. Why would anyone still feel... however they feel?
Maybe it's not that easy for some people to forget.
I'm... trying to understand. The people who hang onto -- grudges. Seems to me they ought to be able to put those feelings aside... once the fighting's done with.
That may be harder to do than to say. You fought the Cardassians, didn't you?
There were some skirmishes... when I was with Captain Maxwell.
Well... how do you feel about them?
Me? I feel... fine. I mean... the war's over now.
Tomorrow night... kidney pie. And then maybe pot roast... beef tongue...
The pursuing ship is the Phoenix.
And the other?
We believe it to be a Cardassian supply ship.
How would you know that?
We... are able to make that determination.
You can read our transponder codes!
What is important at the moment is that your ship may be in jeopardy. Mister Worf -- any answer to our communications?
No, Captain.

Put a repeating message on all sub-space channels. Make it a Priority One communique -- break off pursuit immediately. Gul Macet... as you can see, we are doing everything in our power to reach the Phoenix.
And accomplishing nothing. Can you show me the location of our other ships?
Mister Data.
You see... we have a warship which could intercept the Phoenix before it's too late. If you will give us the transponder frequency.
Or are you going to stand and watch while our ship is destroyed?
Mister Worf -- has there been any response to our hails?
No, sir.
Very well... prepare to relay the transponder code of the Phoenix to the Cardassian warship.
Sir -- ?
And then send a message to Captain Maxwell... advise him that we have relayed his location to the Cardassians.
Begging your pardon, Captain... the transponder code will allow them to track all our ships.
I'm aware of that. Mister Worf -- any response from the Phoenix?
No, Captain.
Mister Data, any change in their their course?
Nossir. The Phoenix is continuing on its bearing toward the supply ship.
Mister Worf... relay the prefix codes of the Phoenix to the Cardassian warship.
Sir, they'll be able to dismantle its shields! The Phoenix won't have a chance.
I cannot allow Maxwell to ambush that supply ship. Mister Worf -- now.
Yes, Captain.
Sir, the Cardassian warship is moving on the Phoenix.
Mister Data, overlay weapon ranges of the two ships...
The warship is three hundred thousand kilometers from the Phoenix. It is opening fire. The Phoenix has taken a direct hit.

The Phoenix is beginning evasive maneuvers. It has positioned itself outside the weapons range of the opposing ship. The Phoenix has powered up with both phasers and photon torpedoes. The Phoenix is firing photon torpedoes.
He has destroyed our warship...
Does the supply ship carry any weapons?
Limited. Not enough to defeat a Nebula Class Starship.
Sir...
The warship carried a crew of six hundred... the supply ship... fifty...
Mister Data... estimated time until we intercept the Phoenix.
At our present speed of warp four, sixteen hours, forty-four minutes.
Ensign, increase to warp nine.
Captain... ?
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: I wanted to... chat with you.
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: Anything I can do, sir, you know that.
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: Ben Maxwell must be quite a man.
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: He's a rare one, all right. I count myself lucky, sir -- I've served with the two finest Captains in Starfleet.
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: Then... from your knowledge of the man... what has gone wrong?
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: There's a reason for what he's doing. Those Cardassians were up to something, I'm sure of it.
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: How did he take it... when his family was killed?
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: I'd say he took it well. Oh, I know he was broken up inside... who wouldn't be? But you'd never know it to see him. He never missed a minute's duty, always had a smile and a joke...
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: I see...
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: And Captain Maxwell, he'd never retaliate out of vengeance, no matter what that Cardassian says. They're up to something... they're the ones you should be investigating, sir, not Captain Maxwell.
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: You don't care for the Cardassians...
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: I like them fine. It's just... well, I know them. You learn to watch your back around those people.
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: Within the last hour... Benjamin Maxwell has sent over six hundred of them to their deaths.
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: I don't know what to say, sir... he must've had his reasons...
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: I think... when one has been angry for a very long time... one gets used to it. Then it becomes comfortable... like old leather. And finally, it is so familiar that one can hardly remember feeling any other way. But in the long run, we are the ones who are damaged by that kind of anger. We are. Not them.
scene: 35   INT. TRANSPORTER ROOM - A LITTLE LATER

quote: Kanar?
Mind if I join you?
You want another? And an ale.
Kanar... never could develop a taste for it.
It takes some getting used to.
I wanted to say... I... I owe you an apology.
Shouldn't have... popped off like that. In the Turbolift.
I think... this is hard on all of us. I know I'll be happy when I'm back on my own ship.
I guess that's true. I hadn't thought of it like that.
I was on Setlik Three.
With Captain Maxwell, the morning after the massacre. We got there too late, of course... almost everyone was dead...
It was a terrible mistake... we were told the outpost was to be the launching place for a massive attack against us...
The only people left alive were in an outlying district of the settlement... I was sent there, with a squad, to reinforce them.

Cardassians were advancing on us, moving through the streets, destroying, killing... I was with a group of women and children when two Cardassian soldiers burst in... I stunned the one, but the other jumped me... we struggled... one of the women threw me a phaser and I fired...
The phaser was set at maximum. The man just... incinerated... there, before my eyes.
I'd never killed anything before. When I was a kid I would worry about having to swat a mosquito.
It's not you I hate, Cardassian. I hate what I became... because of you.
I will protest this, Klingon!
Captain Picard.
Mister Worf, you may release the man.
He was found at a computer station on Deck thirty-five, attempting to access information on our weapon systems.
A lie, Gul Macet. I was studying the terminal interface systems... they are more efficient than ours. I have no idea what was in the files.
What business did you have going near one of their computers?
But... Gul Macet... I meant nothing... there has been no harm done.
Go to your quarters. You are confined there for the duration of this expedition.
As you wish, sir.
Mister Worf, please accompany him.
Gladly.
Captain... may we speak in private?
You have the Bridge, Number One.
Captain, I deeply regret what my aide has done. You have my word that he will be disciplined upon my return.
You may take whatever action against him you feel is appropriate. I consider the matter closed.
I'm not sure I would be so generous in your place, Captain. Thank you.
If there is to be a lasting peace, Gul Macet, neither you nor I must allow any one man to undermine our efforts...

There have always been those who crave war. Who need it. I am not one of them, Captain. I am beginning to see neither are you. We have had our full measure. The lasting peace begins here... with the two of us.
Bridge to Captain.
Picard here.
We have located the Phoenix, Sir. We will intercept in twenty-two minutes.
Captain's log, Stardate 44431.7. We have established communication with Captain Maxwell, and he has agreed to come on board.
Welcome aboard, sir. I'm Commander Riker, First Officer.
I know all about you, Commander. Fine work you did with the Borg. We all owe you on that one.
Thank you, sir.
O'Brien? Miles O'Brien?
Hello, Captain. Good to see you again.
How are you? I had no idea you were on the Enterprise. This was my Tactical Officer on the Rutledge. Best I ever had.
Thank you, sir.
O'Brien has the ability to size up a situation instantly, then come up with options to fit all contingencies. Remarkable.
If that's true, I learned it from you, sir.
But you got that silver tongue by kissing the stone, right? Well, Commander. Best I see your Captain straight away. We have a lot to talk about.
Yes, sir.
What a sweet ship this is... I'll admit, I've always wanted a Galaxy class vessel...
Captain... Gul Macet. He and his aides are guests on the ship.
I see.
Captain Picard is waiting in his Ready Room. This way.
Captain Picard... Captain Benjamin Maxwell.
Captain...
A pleasure. I've heard about you.
Sit down, please. That will be all, Commander.
You must think I've gone mad.
The thought has occurred.
Picard, I have to tell you... I was grateful when I realized it was you Starfleet sent after me. Somebody who knows what it's really like out here.
I know of nothing out here that could justify what you've done.
Then listen to this -- the Cardassians are arming again. That so-called science station? A military supply port.
How do you know this?
Information comes my way.
From whom? Where is your documentation?
You know how these things work... you see things, you hear things... you add them up and you know damn well what's going on.
In other words, you have no documentation...

I know what they're doing. I can smell it. There's no good reason for a science station in the Cuellar System... but it's a hell of a strategic site for a military transport station... a jumping off point into three Federation sectors. They're running supply ships back and forth... and nobody's gonna tell me it's for scientific research...
Whatever circumstances you believed you encountered, why didn't you notify Starfleet?

And wait six months while the bureaucrats sit around reading reports, trying to figure out what to do? They don't know what's going on out here... but you should, Picard, you know what it's like to be under fire...
You weren't under fire.
Lives were at stake...
Whose lives?
We had to act now...
Why?
It smells musty in here... like a bureaucrat's office.
You have killed nearly seven hundred people... taken us to the brink of war...
I have prevented war... or at the very least delayed it a good long time. The peace treaty was a ruse, to give them breathing room, time to regroup...
And so you alone simply decided to dispose of the treaty...
I took the initiative... I did what had to be done...

'What had to be done'? For whom, Maxwell? Why does a man with your long, brilliant service suddenly abandon the fundamental principles that he has believed in, even fought for, all his life... ? I'll tell you what I believe... it was because of what they did to your wife... and your children...
... Not true. Not true...
... to avenge their deaths.
You're a fool, Picard. History will look at you and say 'this man was a fool'.
I'll accept the judgement of history.
When it becomes clear what the Cardassians have done, I will be vindicated.
What the Cardassians have or haven't done is irrelevant...
Irrelevant... come with me and find one of their supply ships and we'll see how irrelevant it is...

We are not going after any more Cardassian ships, Captain Maxwell... you are going to return to your bridge and set a course for Starbase Two-one-one... the Phoenix and the Enterprise will return to Federation space together. I will permit you the dignity of retaining your command during our voyage. My only alternative would be to put you in our brig, while we tow your ship back to starbase in disgrace.
I will return to my ship.
You understand your orders?
Yes, Captain.
Mister Worf, report to my Ready Room. Our guest is departing.
Captain's log, supplemental: With the Phoenix in close formation, we are proceeding directly to Starbase Two-one-one.
Mister Data, how long before we clear Cardassian space?
At our present speed, three hours and twenty minutes.
Mister Worf, send a message to Admiral Haden at Starfleet. Inform him of our projected time of arrival.
Yes, sir.
Captain... the Phoenix is changing course.
What is he doing?!
Ensign, change course to pursue. Mister Worf, hail Captain Maxwell.
No response, sir.
Data, project his new course.
Sir, the Phoenix is heading directly for a Cardassian vessel... point-one-two light years from our location.
He'll attack that ship -- just as he did the others.
Continue your hail, Lieutenant, Priority One message. Do you know what that vessel might be?
I imagine it's a supply ship, headed for the research station in the Kelrabi system. The destruction of our primary science outpost has put an added burden on the others.
The Phoenix still does not respond.
Ensign, warp eight. Overtake him.
Sir, the Phoenix has accelerated to warp nine. We will not be able to reach him before he intercepts the Cardassian ship.
Warp nine, Ensign. Mister Worf, arm phasers... continue hails...
Aye, sir.
Captain, Chief O'Brien was Maxwell's Tactical officer...
Get him up here.
Sir, the Phoenix has dropped out of warp. They have reached the Cardassian vessel.
Slow to impulse.
Vessels are in visual range.
On screen.
Has the Phoenix activated its weapon systems?
Negative, sir. Phaser banks are not armed...
What about the Cardassians?
Our sensors are unable to determine status of the Cardassian defensive systems... Their ship is running with a high-powered subspace field.

Mister O'Brien... your former Commander is about to place me in the unenviable position of having to fire upon another Federation ship. I will need to draw upon your knowledge of the man... how he thinks... what he is capable of doing...
Aye, sir.
Sir, Captain Maxwell is hailing us.
On screen.
All right, Picard, you need proof... you've got it now...
Captain Maxwell, you have disobeyed a direct order...
Board the ship, you'll see that everything I've been saying is true --
The Cardassian ship will not be boarded. You will transport yourself aboard the Enterprise...
Picard, if you don't board that ship, I'll destroy it.
And I will use whatever force is necessary to prevent you from taking that action, Captain.
Sir, Captain Maxwell... if he feels his back is to the wall, he'll strike...
Captain, the Phoenix is transferring power to its shields...
They're arming phasers... loading forward torpedo bays...
Red alert. It appears you are correct, Mister O'Brien.
Ready phasers... load torpedoes...
Phasers ready... loading forward and aft torpedo bays...
Sir? Let me beam over... try to talk to him.
We served together a long time... after you've been through what we have... you kind of get inside a person. He might listen.
He'll never drop his shields to let you transport on board.
The Phoenix is using a high-energy sensor sweep. It cycles every five-point-five minutes. Between those cycles there's a window of a fiftieth of a second. Trust me. I can get through.
Make it so.
It's good we're trying this with another Federation ship. It would never work with an alien vessel.
I'm not so sure it's going to work this time. Can you get an accurate enough fix on his shield modulation to get through?
I think so. The Phoenix should be following standard Starfleet protocols. They have to align their shields at the start of every sweep.
So you'll sync up the beam...
And slip right through...
But if there's any phase error... you could materialize outside the ship... we'd never have a chance to correct.
I've been monitoring his sweep patterns... I'm telling you, I can compensate...
And I guess we could increase the pattern buffer cycle to give us a little more margin for error...
The current cycle is almost finished, sir... they'll be phase aligning in twenty seconds...
Okay, Chief -- let's do it.
Stand by... five seconds... here we go... two... one...
Good luck, Chief.
Not now!
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: I'm not armed.

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: He will, you can count on it.
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: What the hell has happened to this war...
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: You're wrong. The Cardassians live to make war.
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: We're not the same at all. We do not start wars. We do not make surprise attacks on manned outposts. We do not butcher women and children in their homes... children who never got the chance to grow up...
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Yes, sir.
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Stompie. As cool under fire as a mountain lake...
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Yessir.
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: He died at Setlick, didn't he...
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Yessir.
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: What was that song of his... the one he always sang... the one I liked...
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: "The minstrel boy to the war is gone... In the ranks of death you'll find him... "
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: "His father's sword he hath girded on, And his wild harp slung behind him... Land of song, said the warrior bard, Tho all the world betrays thee, One sword at least thy rights shall guard, One faithful harp shall praise thee."
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: I'm not gonna win this one, am I Chief?
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Nossir.
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Maxwell to Bridge. Stand down all weapons.
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Aye, sir.
scene: 48   INT. PHOENIX - CAPTAIN'S READY ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Captain's log, supplemental: Captain Maxwell has turned his ship over to his First Officer and transported aboard the Enterprise. I have confined him to quarters for the return voyage.
I'd just like to say... he's a good man, sir... What he did was terribly wrong, I know that now... but I'm still proud to have served with him.
Thank you, Mister O'Brien. Well done. That'll be all.
His loyalty is admirable... even if it is misplaced.

The loyalty you would so quickly dismiss does not come easily to my people, Gul Macet. You have much to learn about us. Benjamin Maxwell earned the loyalty of those who served with him. In war, he was twice honored with the Federation's highest citation for his courage and valor. And if he could not find a role for himself in peace, we can pity him, but we shall not dismiss him.
You are welcome to your opinion, Captain. I for one am grateful he is under lock and key.
Oh, one more thing, Macet. Maxwell was right. Those ships weren't carrying scientific equipment, were they?
A 'research' station within arm's reach of three Federation sectors... ? Cargo ships running with high energy subspace fields that jam sensors?
If you believed the transport ship carried weapons, why didn't you board it as Maxwell requested?

I was here to protect the peace, a peace I firmly believe is in the interests of both our peoples. But if I had attempted to board that ship... I am quite certain that you and I would not be sitting here now. And that ships on both sides would be arming for war.
Captain, I assure you...
Take a message to your leaders, Gul Macet. We know. We'll be watching. We'll be ready.

I have long been interested in the notion of time travel. In fact, I wrote a book about it... It chronicled the tale of a man from our era who fouled the sixth century by introducing newfangled gadgets and weapons... all in the name of Progress. The idea of time travelers isn't so far fetched as it seems... in fact, I have learned that, even now, people from the future are right here in San Francisco... and I have no doubt that they are intent on fouling our world... just like my Yankee did in King Arthur's time. Well. Let me serve notice: as soon as I get the necessary evidence, I intend to expose them... and make it absolutely clear that they are not welcome here.
scene: 1    EXT. S.F. STREET - CLOSE ON CLEMENS

quote: Yes, sir. And will this be a sequel to "Connecticut Yankee," Mister Twain?

scene: 1    EXT. S.F. STREET - CLOSE ON CLEMENS

quote: With an "e"... got it.
scene: 1    EXT. S.F. STREET - CLOSE ON CLEMENS

quote: 'Scuse me.
scene: 1    EXT. S.F. STREET - CLOSE ON CLEMENS

quote: The coroner said this room contained all the cholera victims...
It doesn't make sense that so many people are dying of cholera -- it just isn't that virulent.
Wil... this is strange...
What is it?
The cerebral cortex... the cerebellum... the brain stem... the entire nervous system -- has been drained of electrochemical energy. Here's another one... same neural depletion...
These people didn't die of cholera -- they died because their neural energy was drained somehow.
Drained... and taken to Devidia Two... for those aliens to ingest.
If you were a time-traveller with a taste for human neural energy... how would you get your supply?
I'd travel back to times when there were plagues and epidemics... when I could murder -- and use disease as a cover.
Over half the victims who'd been drained of neural energy came from a place called Sisters of Hope Infirmary.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: It's a charity hospital near the waterfront.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: If the aliens have been killing people there, someone might have noticed something unusual...
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: If they're moving among humans, they must have taken human form. The question is, how do we know who we're looking for... ?
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: The tricorder picked up evidence of triolic activity in most of the bodies we looked at. If the aliens are leaving that signature behind, they'll be detectable.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: We might even be able to set up some kind of alien alarm system.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Any luck contacting Data?
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: None. The tricorder is broadcasting random emissions... but the range is pretty limited. Almost anything could interfere...
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: She's back.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Mister Picard!
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Coming, Mrs. Carmichael...
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Mister Picard... I'd be remindin' you that it's one o'clock.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Yes... ?
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: One o'clock of a Thursday.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: I'm sure I made it clear to you that the rent is always due, payable in full, by one o'clock on Wednesdays.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Ah. The... rent.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Mrs. Carmichael, my troupe is even now in rehearsals for a new production.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Oh? I haven't heard of any new production. What play is it?
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: It's -- "A Midsummer Night's Dream."
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: We've performed in London... Paris... Milan... all to sold out houses. I assure you, we'll be able to pay the rent... with a bonus.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: No, no, no... I've heard you silver-tongued devils before...
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: I'll have the rent in full... tomorrow... by one o'clock -- or you'll be performing on the street.
scene: 6    INT. BOARDING HOUSE - RENTED ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: I wouldn't do this for just anybody, Mister Clemens. And I hope you won't spread it around that I let you in...

quote: Of course not, Jack. And I assure you -- Mister Data would be most upset if you didn't.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: If I don't find that Letter of Intent he left for me... our major investor is going to pull out and take his business elsewhere.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: It has to do with Mister Data's engine, doesn't it?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Engine...
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Yes... yes... this is exactly what it's all about...
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Mister Clemens... I'm gonna do you another favor today...
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: (still looking at device) Mmmmmm...
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: You're always looking for good stories, right? Well, I've got a humdinger.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Uh-huh...
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: The story of -- my life. Now, I know you might think I'm young... but I've covered a lot of ground, and if I do say so, it'd make for some pretty fascinating reading. So. What do you think?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: About what?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: About writing my life story. You and me -- literary partners.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: You know, son, there's a maxim I've always lived by: no one's more qualified to write your story than you are.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Me? Be a writer? You think I could?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Long as you write what you know... you got any passions, son? Any dreams?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: I'd like to do some travelling... maybe go to sea... and Alaska. I've always had a notion to see Alaska.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: That's a great idea. If I were your age, that's exactly what I'd do... Alaska -- the Klondike... the Aurora Borealis... that's it, follow your dreams. And write about them.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Thank you! Thank you, Mister Clemens. That's just what I'm going to do!
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: You do that, son --
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: You'll be seeing my name in print. London... the name's London.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: I'm sure I will. Good-bye now.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: ... so when I finally got to the Head Surveyor... I found the location of your cavern. But you won't be able to get to it.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Why is that?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: The only entrance is a mine shaft... right in the middle of the Presidio... the Army Fort.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Perhaps you could arrange for us to get in.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: What?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: With permission to dig for the mine shaft.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Data... so far I've been able to do everything you asked me to. But do you really expect me to get you into a high-security military installation?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: I have full confidence in your persuasive abilities.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Well... this is more interesting than giving tea dances.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: That is strange...
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: What?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: I left this device activated... but the transceiver assembly has been removed... without it I will be unable to track the time shifts.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Clemens.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Samuel Clemens?
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: He's been driving me crazy. He watches the house, follows me down the street asking questions -- I'd bet you anything he got in here and took your -- whatever you said.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: If you are correct, he must be told that the device has been modified in such a way that prolonged contact with human tissue would be highly toxic.
scene: 7    INT. DATA'S HOTEL ROOM - SAME DAY (OPTICAL)

quote: Madame Guinan... Mister Data... good day.
Mister Clemens... shame on you.
Shame, madame? I think not. I find no shame in my efforts to uncover your plot.
I keep telling you, there is no plot --

Yes... you do keep telling me that. (a beat, as he regards her) Mister Data, did you know that Madame Guinan here is from a renowned Boston family... a close relative of Judge Truman Williams? I believe that's what you said...
Yes.
Then... I wonder... why the Judge says he's never heard of you? That's what his telegram to me indicated...
There's been a blood feud between two branches of the family. He doesn't acknowledge me.
Ah. That must wound you deeply.
What an interesting pair you are... an Ashanti princess... and a Swiss. Where in Switzerland are you from, Mister Data?
I am French, not Swiss.

Of course, that's right... now I remember. A Frenchman with a talent for poker, from what I hear. You know, I was talking with a friend of mine, Ches Whitley... he said to say hello... wonders when you're coming back.
I do not believe I know Mister Whitley.

No? He works at the County Assayer's Office... said you've been in there several times... claiming to be a geological engineer. Wanting information about mining operations during the 1850's... Remember him now?
I do not know the gentleman by name. I have spoken to several people in that office.
Yes... I know. And in the Hall of Records... and the Geological Society... and a little-known mineral shop in Chinatown. You do get around, don't you?
As apparently you do, Mister Clemens.
I must admit -- you've got me mystified.
This contraption, for instance. Very unusual. It looks quite -- futuristic. Tell me -- might it have something to do with "time shifts"?
In a sense. The time shift is a new gearing system that I have invented... for a horseless carriage.

Do not insult me. You've come to this century and brought your infernal technology with you... for God only knows what purpose... but I have no doubt that it will be the people of this century who will suffer for it.
Mister Clemens, I think we've had quite enough of this. Mister Data's business is his own, and I'd thank you to leave.
Pardon me, Madame, but it is my business... it is the business of all humanity, I believe, to stop both of you from whatever it is you are doing here. And that is what I intend to do.
He won't last the day.
Aren't we going to treat him?
I wish we could. But at this point there's nothing to be done. Unless you know of some miracle treatment.
Why don't we try an alkaline saline solution... to counteract dehydration?
Nurse, if that were helpful, don't you think I would have ordered it?
Now, you finish the charts and leave the practice of medicine to me.
Yes, Doctor.
... did your friend have any visitors before he died?
No... had no family... only people to come were doctor and nurse.
Very bad doctor.
Only spent time with one man. I ask for water... he ignore me. Others cry in pain... doctor does not care. Very bad.
Hello, Officer. This the Infirmary?
Yes. The entrance is right there.
Just what is it you're doing with those lamps?
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: Replacing the wick screws. City ordinance... makes it safer in case of an earthquake.
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: There hasn't been an earthquake here in thirty years.
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: That's it for this ward. Have to be moving on.
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: Earthquakes... Nurse, if you can handle things here, I have a meeting with the Board of Patrons.
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: I'm sure I'll manage.
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: There... by that bed. I can see an afterimage of triolic waves. They were here recently... within the last twenty-four hours.
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: That's the bed where someone died last night...
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: (pointing to the male patient) This man was complaining about a strange doctor and nurse who visited that patient. They might still be in the hospital.
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: This will make you more comfortable...
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: Do you need any help, Doctor?
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: Doctor Apollinaire felt he had entered the algid stage... he was cyanotic, pulse unobservable...
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: That's an interesting cane...
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: Hold it!
scene: 12   INT. INFIRMARY - A FEW MINUTES LATER

quote: What's all this? What's going on here?
Apparently a distraught relative... she became quite upset... we tried to calm her but she ran out.
I heard an explosion...
(as if he's just arrived) How about it? You people see any explosion?
There was nothing like that, Officer...
Okay, folks, I suggest you all clear out and let the patients have a little peace... sorry, Doctor.
People said there was gunfire in here... What's going on?
Just a misunderstanding... I'm clearing these people out of here.
I've never seen you before...
Just got assigned this morning. Usually work downtown.
I worked downtown for three years... I don't remember you.
Hold it!
I'm going to ask all of you to come down to the station for questioning. Including you. Let's go...
Where'd you get that? That's a gentleman's cane.
Never saw a cane like this before. I'll have to confiscate it. Evidence.
I want you to know... I have only the greatest respect for the law.
Data!
Boy, am I glad to see you!
I would suggest we postpone our greetings for another occasion.
Agreed. Let's get out of here.
If we tune a phaser to the approximate frequency of triolic waves, and lay down a field burst... it might respond.
The ophidian the aliens were carrying...
What the...
Minute space-time distortions... like the one we saw on Devidia Two...
But they were so small... and they only lasted a second...
The aliens seem to have the ability to concentrate the distortion -- and direct it toward a specific time and destination.
Maybe they have something... a -- mechanism, that focuses it.
Any device like that would produce significant levels of triolic waves... ... like the ones in the cavern where Data's head was found.
I have located that cavern --
Mister Picard!
I know you're in there! Open the door!
Mrs. Carmichael... thank goodness you're here.
How now, spirit! whither wander you?
Over hill, over dale, Through bush, through brier, Over park, over pale...
Ah -- just in time! We need someone to read a part...
Mister Picard, I need to be talkin' to you...
Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.
Now, Mrs. Carmichael... Right there...
Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.
What, jealous Oberon. Fairies skip hence. I have foresworn his bed and company.
Well, I don't need to hear any more. That was -- truly unique.
Really?
I think we've found our Titania... ... don't you agree?
Well... I did do a church play when I was a lass...
You see? We'll begin rehearsals tomorrow.
What theatre did you say?
There you are! I have good news -- we can get into the Presidio --
It is all right.

General Mallory is usually a stickler for the rules... but I happen to know that his wife thinks she's a singer. So I told him she simply must perform at my next gathering... and the rules just... disappeared.
You know me...
Very well.
Do I know you?
Not yet. But you will.
Thanks for your help, Officer.
Make sure you put in the part about me spotting that phony policeman.
Yessir, I will.
H'lo, son...
Mister Clemens... what brings you here?
A writer's curiosity...
I heard two people vanished into thin air in this Infirmary.
One of the patients said that, yessir. But the police deny it.
I'll bet they do...
They say a band of outlaws set off an explosion in the hospital... then escaped.
What did these outlaws look like?
The carriage they escaped in was driven by an albino...
Ah. Mister Data.
You know him?
You bet I do. You say there were others with him?
Yes -- at least a dozen.
His accomplices... they've come from the future -- my God, it's an invasion.
An invasion... from the future? Mister Clemens... what can you tell me about this? Do you have any proof?
Young man... when's your deadline?
Five o'clock, sir.
I'll meet you at your paper at four-thirty... with a story that will make your career.
Thanks, Mister Clemens...
Take me to the Presidio, driver. And don't spare the whip.
The triolic levels are as high as they were on Devidia Two... ... but no indication of any control mechanism.
I'm not so sure.
My VISOR is picking up crystalline fractures. These cavern walls have undergone some kind of selective molecular polarization.
In fact, if I'm right... this whole cavern has been configured to focus the space-time distortion... just like a lens.
Captain, we think we're on to something. The cavern itself seems to be acting as a focusing mechanism... and I'm betting the same is true of their habitat back on Devidia Two.
If we can get back there... and destroy that site... can we put an end to their time traveling... ?
We have the ophidian...
But I don't know if it will work. The energy our phasers generate may not be entirely compatible with the ophidian.
We have no choice but to try.
An event I would most certainly enjoy witnessing...
Move along... I suspect even time travellers are vulnerable to a Colt Forty-Five. (removes watch, glances at it) Let's go -- I've made a young fellow a promise and I don't want to be late.
Follow him!
Is everybody all right?
I think so...
You--!
(rising to his feet, brushing himself off) Where are we -- and when is this?
It's the twenty-fourth century... this is Devidia Two -- and you shouldn't be here.
Seems to me I have as much right to be in your time as you had to be in mine. You see, sir, I wanted to see how you've conducted my future affairs.
Your future affairs?
The affairs of mankind.
Don't you see -- the disappearance of Mark Twain... one of the most noted literary figures of the nineteenth century...
Thank you...
... that's not supposed to happen.
I have only taken advantage of an irresistible occasion... as any good writer would.
Bridge to Away Team... acknowledge.
We're here, Mister Worf. How long have we been gone?
You have been off sensor displays for almost nine days, sir.
Stand by to transport five...
Commander...
Mister Worf... six to transport.
Where are we... ?
The Federation Starship Enterprise. Chief, call security. We need an escort for this man.
Security? What for?
A werewolf...
It's a long story, Mister Worf... I'll brief you later.
Have Data's body brought to the Medical Lab. I'm going to try to re-attach the head we have.
That head is almost five hundred years old...
It's the best chance we've got.
I want Mister Clemens here under escort at all times.
Commander... perhaps I could handle that. I'd be happy to take Mister Clemens to quarters.
Good idea. If you would accompany the Counselor...
Madame... I'd be delighted.
So this is a space ship, eh? Did you ever run into Halley's comet?
Whoa... everything's spinning...
Don't try to sit up too quickly... you've lost a lot of blood.
Where'd... everybody go... ?
I hope they're safely back on the Enterprise by now.
You're still here...
You were hurt. I had to make sure you were all right.
You stayed here... for that... ?
I can't very well let anything happen to you... you're far too important to me.
You know... so much about me...
Believe me, in the future the tables will be turned.
We... become friends...
It goes beyond friendship.
But... I have to wait... almost five hundred years... And when we meet... I won't be able to tell you about this, will I?
No. Because for me, it won't have happened yet.
What happened... ?
History fulfilling itself...
History has to fulfill itself. Even Picard knew that.
You were there, in the cavern. You know what happened. What am I supposed to do?
Damn it, Guinan, don't play games with me... I need answers.
If I tell you what happened in that cavern, it would affect any decision you're about to make. I can't do that. I won't do that.
Not telling me might affect my decision, too... did you think of that?
We're talking about Jean-Luc Picard. I'm not going to sit around and hope it all works out... I've got to do something...
Any place that doesn't stock a good cigar doesn't rank high in my book.
If you must have one, I'm sure we could replicate it for you.
You think one of those -- imitations -- could take the place of a hand-wrapped Havana?
I wouldn't know...
That's the problem I see here... all this technology... it only serves to take away life's simple pleasures. You don't even let a man open a door for a lady.
I think what we've gained outweighs anything that might have been lost...
Oh? I'm not so impressed with this future... huge starships... weapons that can no doubt destroy entire cities... military conquest as a way of life.
Is that what you see here?
Oh, I know what you say... this is a vessel of exploration... your mission is to, discover new worlds...
Deck thirty-six.

That's what the Spanish said... and the Dutch, and the Portuguese. It's what all conquerors say... I'm sure it's what you told that blue skinned fellow I just saw... before you brought him here to serve you.
He's one of thousands of species we've encountered. We live in a peaceful Federation with many of them... the people you see are here by choice.
So there are a privileged few... who serve on these ships, living in luxury, wanting for nothing. But what about everyone else? What about the poor? You ignore them...
Poverty was eliminated a long time ago. And a lot of things disappeared with it: hopelessness... despair... cruelty... war...

I come from a time when men achieve wealth and power by standing on the backs of the poor... when prejudice and intolerance are commonplace... when power is an end unto itself... And you're telling me... that isn't how it is anymore?
That's right.
Maybe it is worth giving up cigars for, after all...
Tell me.... how long was it... before things began to change?
A long time. The people of your lifetime won't see it.
Is it working?
Not so far. His restart units won't initialize.
I thought his buffering program would have protected them... but I guess five hundred years was just too long a wait.
My watch...
It was found in the cavern... near Data's head. After five hundred years, I doubt that it'll work either.
Mister Data... I fear I sadly misjudged you. As I have misjudged many things.
Can you communicate?
Yes...
Are you injured?
Why have you interfered?
You hunt us... you kill us. We cannot allow that.
We need your energy...
Perhaps we could find a substitute...
No... there is none... we must continue.
We cannot allow that. We know how you move back and forth through time... my crew has returned to the twenty-fourth century to destroy your transport site on Devidia Two --
Destroy it?
Your weapons will only amplify the time distortion... you will annihilate your own world...
I'm going back for the Captain... Mister Worf, prepare an Away Team to accompany me to the surface. Doctor, I need to know anything you can tell me about that ophidian.
I've just started running some tests. If I could have a few hours...
We can't give the aliens any more time...
Wil, I haven't been able to determine if our phaser energy can generate a stable field. The risk would be --
I accept the risk.
Sir... permission to speak frankly?
Go ahead.
Our priority is to stop the aliens from making any more incursions to Earth. Any delay is unacceptable.
If I can save Captain Picard, I consider it very acceptable.
The Captain would not. I recommend we target photon torpedoes on the alien habitat and destroy it immediately.
He's right, Wil.
Mister Worf, power up the photons. Inform me when you're ready.
Computer... calibrate the power flow polarity selector...
Polarity selector is calibrated.
Computer... initialize the re-load circuits.
Re-load circuits are initializing.
C'mon, Data... this ought to do it...
Okay, Computer... deactivate the polarity selector. I don't get it... why isn't this working?
Computer, run a diagnostic on the input polarizers.
There is intermittent contact in the input polarizers.
Intermittent?
An iron filing... how did that get in there?
Commander, I have set the photons to fire in staggered rounds, detonating in ten-second intervals.
Very well. Fire when ready.
The sequence will be ready to initiate in one minute.
Computer, try another diagnostic on the input polarizers.
Polarizer circuits are functioning.
Then that should do it...
Okay, Data... come on, now...
...torpedoes... don't phasing... aliens...
I am processing a binary message that was entered into my static memory by Captain Picard. Geordi, are we planning to fire on the alien habitat?
Yeah, but --
It is imperative that we do not. I will explain later.
La Forge to Riker -- hold your fire!
The binary message left by the Captain is not entirely clear. He seemed to be concerned about the phase differential of our photon torpedoes... that firing them might produce a catastrophic effect.
Then how do we destroy their habitat?
If I am correct... we must modify our weapons so that the force of the explosion is re-phased into the aliens' time continuum.
If we outfit the photons with phase discriminators... we could get the necessary variance.
How long will it take you?
At least a couple of hours.
Fine. That'll give me time to go get him.
Sir?
There's time now... I'm going back to the nineteenth century for the Captain. Doctor... ?
My analysis of the phasers suggests you'd be able to open a rift... but it won't be stable enough to transport more than one person.
You mean... if I go back... only one of us could return.
That's right.
Then I have the perfect solution for you.
I'm the one who should return to the nineteenth century, Commander... and remain there so your Captain can return.
There's a risk... we're not certain how stable the rift will be...
There's risk in everything. The point is -- it's the right choice. I have more books to write... your Captain has a job to do here...
Mister La Forge... brief him on what he'll need to do.
I'm glad I have the chance to thank you.
For what?
For starting me on the greatest adventure a man's ever had. For helping a bitter old man open his eyes... so he can see that the future turns out pretty well, after all.
Guinan...
...thirsty...
I'm going to get help. We have to get you out of here...
...wait... stay a while... maybe they'll come for you...
No. You need help.
This thing put me down in the middle of Market Street. It took forever to get here...
Sir, Commander La Forge has completed the re-configuration of the photon torpedoes.
If Clemens got back, the Captain should have been here by now.
We have no way of knowing if Mister Clemens was successful.
Re-establish your firing pattern, Mister Worf. We'll wait five more minutes.
Yes, Commander.
No time for chit-chat, sir... According to Mister La Forge -- who did get your message by the way -- a frequency setting of point-oh-four-seven on your phaser will correctly activate this creature.
You'll have to get help. Guinan needs medical attention...
I promise you she will be attended to.
We have a bill at Mrs. Carmichael's boarding house --
It will be settled.
Thank you. I wish time had allowed me to know you better...
You'll just have to read my books. What I am is pretty much there.
I'll see you in five hundred years, Picard.
I'll see you... in a few minutes.
Commander... I am picking up massive triolic wave activity on the surface.
Is it the Captain?
There are no human life signs.
No sign of a temporal distortion?
No, sir. But triolic activity is increasing.
The aliens...
Mister Worf, are the photons ready?
Yes, sir.
Fire.
Torpedoes away, sir.
Commander -- I am detecting a temporal distortion on the surface... and human life signs.
O'Brien -- get him out of there!
Transporter Room -- do you have him?
He does indeed, Commander. And believe me... it's good to be back.
We have destroyed the target, sir. There is no further indication of triolic activity.
Ensign, lay in a course to the nearest Starbase. Warp six.
Captain's Log, Stardate 46001.3.

Everyone who should be in the nineteenth century is safely there, and those who should be in the twenty-fourth are here. Mister Data has been restored to us, head and all... and Samuel Clemens will write the books he was to have written after our encounter.
Be careful not to jostle her too much, boys... Don't worry... you're going to be fine...
Captain's Log, Stardate 46235.7 Ensign Ro, Keiko O'Brien, Guinan and I are returning to the Enterprise after a fascinating visit to the planet Marlonia.
... and I found these pieces in the tertiary level of the dig. They're typical of second century Marlonian cookware.
Mmmm-hmmmm.
Now, see these markings... they're very similar to some early Taguan designs... but the patterns are more intricate... closer to Buranian than Taguan.
So... you went to one of the most beautiful planets in this quadrant and spent your entire shore leave... in a cave.
It was a very rewarding experience. Look at these fragments... they're in nearly perfect condition... and they're over seven hundred years old.
So's my father.
Is that a Draebidium Froctus?
Draebidium Calimus actually... you can tell by the shape of the leaves.
I didn't know you were interested in plant biology.
I... took a class at the Academy... I just remember a few things...
Enterprise to Shuttlecraft Fermi...
This is the Fermi. Go ahead Enterprise.
We have just received a distress signal from the Starfleet science team on Ligos Seven.
Any indication of the problem?
No, sir. The call was cut off mid-transmission.
Lay in a course and prepare to engage at Warp eight once we're aboard.
Aye, sir.
We'll rendezvous with the ship in three minutes, sir.
We're caught in some kind of energy field.
Hard about, full impulse.
Aye, sir.
What's happening, Mister Worf?
The shuttle's been enveloped by an energy field, sir.
Their engines and life support have failed.
Increase to full impulse. Bridge to Transporter Room Three. Prepare to beam the shuttle crew aboard once we're in range.
Ready, sir.
There's too much interference... I can't contact the Enterprise...
Transfer auxiliary power to the inertial dampers...
Warning. Structural failure imminent.
O'Brien, do you have them?
I'm trying, sir... I can't get a pattern lock.
The shuttle's coming apart, Chief. You've got to do it now.
I've got them. There's a forty percent drop in mass. I may have lost one of them...
Thank you, Mister O'Brien. Another moment and...
According to the bio-scans, their DNA structures are now consistent with those of pre-adolescents. But as far as I can tell, only their bodies have changed.
Their individual intelligence and behavioral responses are all exactly the same as they were before the accident.
What happened to the shuttlecraft, Number One?
The shuttle broke up just after we beamed you out. Data's coordinating the salvage effort right now. Sir.
What about the energy field the shuttle passed through?
We've been trying to scan it, but it's putting out a lot of interference. It's going to take some time.

We can't afford to stay here any longer. We'll leave a class four probe behind to study the energy field but the distress signal from Ligos Seven has top priority. Let me know as soon as you have any further information, Doctor. Number One, you're with me.
Captain... there are some additional tests I'd like to run...
Of course... The three of you will remain as needed to assist Doctor Crusher.
What?
You know... you make a pretty cute kid.
Great. Just what I want to be... cute.
Were you this much fun when you were a kid?
I was in a refugee camp. "Fun" wasn't exactly in my vocabulary.
What about now? You're not in that camp anymore.
"Fun" is being back at work... in my own uniform.
Bridge.
Mister Worf. Prepare to launch a class four probe to study the energy field.

I realize how unusual this must seem... My appearance is the result of an accident, involving myself and three other crew members... the effects of which Doctor Crusher is currently working to remedy. I assure you, I am Captain Picard.
The probe. Aye, sir.
Mister Data, have you secured all of the shuttle debris?
Almost, sir. It is being stored in Shuttlebay Two.
Very well. Ensign, as soon as Mister Data is finished take us to Ligos at warp eight.
Captain, may I see you privately for a few moments?
Of course.
Tea. Earl Grey. Hot. Have you been able to determine the cause of our transformation?
Not yet. I'm still waiting for some test results.
I see.
There are one hundred and three members of the science team on Ligos Seven. We should prepare shuttlebay three for a triage center in case they have large numbers of casualties.
We'll be ready.
Ligos Seven is prone to periodic volcanic activity... perhaps the planet has entered an active phase---
Jean-Luc. I think we need to talk.
All right. Let's talk. Are you here to relieve me of duty?
I'd rather not have to take that step.
I am still Jean-Luc Picard. My judgement, my experiences, my mental capacities are all intact.
That's true... for now. This could be the first stage of a condition which may begin to affect your mind as well.
But you've seen no evidence of that?
Not yet. What I do know is that the Captain of this ship has just gone through an extreme physical transformation... the ultimate effects of which I can't even begin to guess.
You are asking me to step down.
You're still Jean-Luc Picard... what do you think you should do?
Commander Riker, please take command of the ship until further notice.
Understood, sir.
So what the hell am I supposed to do now?
You're not supposed to do anything. That's what "relieved of duty" means.
Well, I should be doing something... instead of just standing around waiting for them to find a cure.
You're right. Let's go play.
What?
I haven't been young for a long time... and I intend to enjoy every minute of it.
Fine. Enjoy yourself.
What are you going to do... go back to your room and pout?
I am not twelve years old. If I want to go to my quarters and contemplate my situation, it does not mean that I am... pouting.
Okay, okay.
I could use a... cup of coffee. How about you?
I'll get it. Two coffees... one with cream...
Black... double sweet...
I know. One double sweet.
Careful... that's hot...
Miles...
Sorry.
What's wrong?
It's... I don't know... but this feels wrong, somehow.
Miles Edward O'Brien. I am still your wife.
Technically, yes.
Technically?
No. I mean, of course you're my wife... but you're also ten years old.
Beverly said it's actually closer to twelve.
That's not the point.
So what is the point? Is our marriage over?
I didn't say that. But until they find a way to reverse this... this effect... it's going to be hard for me to ignore the fact that you're a little girl.
What if they can't find a way? What if I'm like this the rest of my life? What does that mean for us, for our family?
Mommy?
What's wrong, Sweetheart?
I want Mommy to read me a story.
All right. What story would you like to hear?
I want Mommy.
What if Daddy reads you a story tonight? Will that be okay?
I'll be right back.
Keiko...
It's going to be all right... I promise... we'll work this out...
How?
I don't know.

First Officer's Log: Supplemental. The Enterprise has reached the Ligos system, and we have begun to search for the missing Federation science team. Doctor Crusher reports no progress on finding a cure for the members of the shuttle crew.
Come.
I came to see how you're doing.
I'll have to speak to my tailor, but otherwise I'm well, thank you.
It's just so... ridiculous. I can't really take myself seriously like this...
What's wrong?
Counselor... if Doctor Crusher can't find a cure... and I have to stay this way... no one's going to take me seriously, are they?

I would say the people who know you, who've worked with you for years, will be able to make the adjustment eventually. But... there are some cultures that would not accept a twelve-year-old captain as a negotiating partner or a credible emissary.
In that case, I suppose I'll have to wait until... I grow up again before I'll get another command. That could be ten years... maybe fifteen...
The question is... what to do until then?
You're still a captain... I'm sure there are other assignments you could be given.
I've spent thirty years of my life aboard starships... I'm not about to sit behind a desk now.
You could return to the Academy... get another degree... brush up on your Latin.

And be Wesley's room-mate, I suppose. I will admit that returning to the Academy does have a certain appeal... but I've always spent my life looking forward... going to the Academy again feels like... looking back.
Then perhaps you could use this time to explore another interest... archeology for instance?
Leave Starfleet?
Not permanently... just a sabbatical. You could spend ten years crawling through caves and digging up artifacts... and still have enough time to become the youngest admiral in Starfleet.
It would give me a chance to accompany Doctor Langford on her exploration of the ruins on Suvin Four... but to leave the Enterprise...
In a way, you're very lucky. You have a chance do what most people can only dream about... have a second childhood without the pain of growing up.

This is Captain Picard's rybo-viroxic-nucleic structure from a tissue sample I took this morning. It's the same as a sample I took before the accident -- except it's missing several key viroxic sequences.
